PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Prime Minister indicate in which industry sectors of the economy, which regions and which age groups the 800,000 jobs promised by Mr Keating in his Ein Volk statement will be concentrated?

—No, of course I could not do that; nor could the Opposition in any document it has published. All the Opposition can predict is that if we hang in there in a period of misery for the next 10 years there will be some relief for the unemployed.
—Two million jobs.
—`Two million jobs', `Turn on the lights'—all the great Liberal Party phrases of the past are reincarnated in this two million jobs at the end of the century or somewhere like that.
—Talk about your 800,000.

—Senator Hill keeps interjecting, `Talk about your 800,000'. Straight away the Opposition started about its two million jobs; I too am starting about its two million in answer to interjections from that side of the House. Looking at any of the scenarios in documents published by the Opposition and confirmed by economists who have advised the Opposition about this package, the scenarios are ones of misery and distress for the next five to 10 years for the unemployed in this country. And Senator Baume bounces up here and asks me where 800,000 jobs will be found over a shorter period in the life of this Government!

PARA.TAB: I am surprised that Senator Baume asked me in which industries and in which regions. That is not a thing he has been particularly specific about in plucking this two million figure out of the air. When growth returns to the Australian economy, of course, the employment situation improves significantly. If Senator Baume wants me to suggest particular areas where there will be high growth in employment, according to the anticipations of the Government—

TALK.START.PARA: —The car industry?

—First of all, the tourist industry is one in which we project significant improvements in employment. Senator Kemp, who is an emigre from that rusty think-tank in Melbourne, comes up here and talks about the car industry. In 1985, when Senator Kemp was at his daddy's knee—a classic example of nepotism in think-tanks, if ever there was one—he might have known that this Government said that employment in the motor vehicle industry would decline for the remaining years of this century. That is what we said, because that is reality. It is quite distinct from these cloud-cuckoo-land figures the Opposition has plucked out of the air in respect of the package it has put together in an abortive attempt to raise some enthusiasm for a lost cause.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I noticed that the Minister said, first of all, that he could not indicate any industry, region or age group and then proceeded to outline one industry alone—only one; the tourist industry. In that case, is the Minister saying that he cannot indicate what the Keating package will do to cut the 18.9 per cent unemployment rate reported by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for north-west Melbourne or how many of the 13,800 jobs wiped out in that region over the last 12 months will be restored?

—I thought Senator Baume had those figures and, in another stunt of his, threw them into the streets of Wills in a demonstration. The fact of the matter is, as he well knows, that as an economy comes out of recession jobs will grow throughout the economy. That is a fact. If that is not true, the Opposition's whole consumption tax package is an absolute mockery in terms of any signs of hope it holds for anybody.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume wants me to be more specific. Of course there will be growth in some sectors of the Australian economy and, in terms of employment, there will be long term decline in others. That is what restructuring an economy is about. It is something that the coalition never tried and never took on in all its golden years of government. Fightback—this consumption tax proposal—is designed to screw up the psyche of the Liberal Party, which never took on any of these things in all its history in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Industrial Relations advise honourable senators whether the union movement has confirmed its commitment to wage outcomes which are consistent with Australia maintaining an inflation rate comparable with those of our major trading partners? Will this commitment enable Australians to achieve the strategy outlined in the Prime Minister's One Nation package aimed at creating 800,000 jobs?

—Last Friday in Melbourne the Government and the ACTU met. The ACTU has confirmed that it will defer its national wage case application which, under last October's national wage case decision, would be able to come on in May of this year. The ACTU has confirmed that that application will be deferred until the latter part of this year; that it will confer with the Government as to the amount of its claim and the timing of its application; that it does this in order to lock in a low level of inflation as portrayed in the One Nation statement; that it does this as well in a cooperative frame of mind to help achieve the 800,000 new jobs that the Government will create because of the One Nation statement; and that the basis of determining a future wage application will be a consideration of the inflation rates among Australia's leading trading partners.

PARA.TAB: This is a very fine example of the Australian union movement putting jobs and economic recovery first. It is a fine example, too, of the Government being able to work with the union movement to achieve an outcome for this country which is in the interests of all citizens of this country. It is an example that cannot be emulated by the Opposition in any way, shape or form. Indeed, the Hewson consumption tax package involves confrontation with and, in the words of Dr Hewson himself, destruction of the Australian trade union movement to succeed on the wage assumptions that he has projected.

The preferred scenario worked up under the Chris Murphy model envisages that, to fill a hole of something like $10 billion in cuts for health and social welfare without any compensation, there will be no industrial pressure to regain the loss that those cuts will produce for workers and for those who receive those services. The most probable scenario under the Murphy model—the wages up scenario, as he chooses to call it—is one that, if it is not to be realised, requires the destruction of the union movement, plain and simple. That is what the Opposition has embarked upon—conflict rather than cooperation.

We have succeeded in making all of the estimates in the One Nation statement solid. They are now solid estimates and the outcomes that they envisage will be worked cooperatively through with the union movement to the benefit of this economy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security to today's damning social justice critique by ACOSS of the Government's squalid tax proposals in which its President, Mrs Mitchell, says:

QUESTION.PARA: Many people will in fact be worse off due to the failure to increase the tax free area in line with inflation and because there is no cut in their marginal tax rates. Many families, especially those on two incomes will also be worse off.

Will the Minister care to explain where Mrs Mitchell is wrong in her assessments and, if he cannot, will he concede that the inevitable consequences of this divisive and heartless tax reform proposal are that the Government is deliberating exacerbating social inequities in order to create two nations rather than one?

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Alston ought to be aware, the whole thrust of government reforms in the social security area right throughout the 1980s was directed to low income families. That is why we ended the pernicious practices of the Fraser Government in refusing to index all of those basic payments that were made to them. That is why Brian Howe, during his tenure as Minister, introduced family payments such that Australia had simply never, ever seen before. That does not even include the changes that were made to the tax thresholds at the time and, indeed, to marginal rates.

PARA.TAB: The real increases delivered to families were very substantial. The economic statement of last week has been directed to improving the standard of living of people, especially those on DSS payments. As an example, a pensioner couple with two children has received a real increase of 22 per cent, or 28 per cent if renting privately. A pensioner couple with no children has received a real increase of 13 per cent, or 18 per cent if renting privately. A single pensioner has received a real increase of 14 per cent, or 21 per cent if renting privately.

Low income working families have also benefited substantially from the large increases in family payments and family allowance supplement payments. Combined family payments have risen by 37 per cent for a family with one child under 13; 83 per cent for a family with one teenage child; 28 per cent for a family with two children under 13 years of age; and 70 per cent for a family with two teenage children. The real increases in the family allowance supplement are a far more effective way, a far more targeted way, of improving the disposable incomes of those on low incomes. It is much better than changing tax thresholds and raising rebates, because many low income families simply do not get the benefit from doing that.

Nevertheless, the Government has also raised thresholds and rebates and has removed the intermediate tax bracket. Between 1983 and 1992 the Government raised the tax threshold from $4,595 to $5,400; replaced the 29c in the dollar tax bracket for incomes between $12,600 and $19,500 a year with a tax bracket which is only 20c in the dollar for up to $20,700 a year; and increased the dependent spouse rebate from $830 to $1,149 and the sole parent rebate from $780 to $1,080, and has indexed both. The Government has also greatly reduced the effective taxation on pensioners and allowees by increasing pensioner and beneficiary rebates to exempt full rate pensioners and allowees with no private income from taxation and by removing many of the poverty traps from the pensions and benefits system, such as the simultaneous income testing of base payments and rent assistance.

So it is very hard to argue a case that the Government has not been attending to the needs of low income families. We spent nine years making that a priority. That having been done throughout the 1980s and continuing into the 1990s, what the statement did last week was introduce a payment of $3 per week per child additional in the family allowance supplement. As well as that, the statement has to be read with the last Budget measure of changing the threshold on the family allowance supplement. That is an extraordinary record, one of which everyone on this side of the chamber is proud.

When it came to formulating this statement, the fact that the Prime Minister and the Government should then choose to give some tax relief to those who have borne the brunt of what occurred during the 1980s—that is, those on incomes between $20,000 and $40,000—should come as no surprise. What the Government has managed to do over the course of the last nine years is make sure that benefits have flowed to all those who need them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it that the Minister is, in effect, conceding that the low income earners have had it too good for too long; that we ought to get back to ancient history—which I thought his Leader was not in the business of doing; and that we ought to say that all the good things that the Government claims to have done for these people in the 1980s is sufficient reason for now disadvantaging them through the tax system. If that is not right, can the Minister tell me where Mrs Mitchell is wrong, or else concede that these people will be relatively worse off as a result of this Government's changes to the tax system?

—I do not make any such concession. I can only repeat that the massive cash payments that were made available to low income families during the course of the 1980s that were not available before—or, when they were available, were never indexed before—represented, I think, a great leap forward for those on low incomes in Australia. So, as far as the Government is concerned, we stand by all those things that we did in the 1980s, and we look forward to doing many more in the 1990s.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Can the Minister tell the Senate what effect the Government believes the reduction in sales tax on motor vehicles from 20 per cent to 15 per cent will have on demand for cars? The Government last year outlined motor industry arrangements which come into effect after 1992. Can the Minister explain why the Government has now decided to cut sales tax? Can the Minister assure the Senate that the car manufacturers will pass on in full to the consumers the benefits of the sales tax reduction?
—The reduction in sales tax on motor vehicles announced in the Prime Minister's statement is a structural change.
—It is a bit late in coming.

—I agree with that interjection because for many years—decades, in fact—the sales tax on motor vehicles in Australia has been structured on the antediluvian notion that motor cars are a luxury item and, therefore, should bear a special rate of tax higher than anything else. That is the origin of that tax structure, and it went on for a long time. The fact of the matter is that the reduction in sales tax will bring us more into line with international tax regimes applying to the motor vehicle industry. For example, we had one of the highest indirect taxes on motor vehicles before this change was made—the only exceptions being one or two Scandinavian countries—and that is the reason why the change was made.

PARA.TAB: In so far as the benefits to the industry are concerned, we believe that some benefits will flow to the industry in terms of lower prices as a result of the reduction in the sales tax. Those benefits are important. The motor vehicle industry is a very large industry in Australia. It employs a lot of people and, through the components sector, it generates a lot of export earnings for this country. So it is important that this industry, which has been through difficult times as a consequence of the recession, should receive some stimulus in terms of the reduction of wholesale sales tax occurring at this time.

Of course, the linkages with other industries are also important in respect of the motor vehicle industry, and those benefits will flow through. Similarly, the benefits from the depreciation regime changes announced in the Prime Minister's statement will flow through to the motor vehicle industry.

I might say, in answer to the last part of the honourable senator's question, that the Government expects that the manufacturing producers in the motor vehicle industry will pass through the effects of the sales tax reductions to consumers. I have spoken to each of the chief executives of the motor vehicle companies and said that that was the wish and intention of the Government. In so far as some of them are concerned, that sales tax has already been passed on, I understand, in recent prices. That will be monitored by the Automotive Industry Authority to make sure that that happens as a consumer benefit, which in turn will be of benefit to the motor vehicle industry.
In respect of the remarks made by some commentators, who see a reduction in wholesale sales tax as an increase in protection to the motor vehicle industry, just let me make the point—

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been said.

—It has been said, and it has been said by rather shallow people, I think. The fact of the matter is that those reductions will, of course, apply to imported vehicles as well as to locally produced vehicles. How that can be argued to be an increase in protection to the local industry I am not quite clear, but certain people are keen to make that argument at any time, at any point, and for reasons which increasingly elude me.

—Mr Bill Sterling, an economist for Merrill Lynch, in responding to the package said that Australia is on the right track. Mr Ian Salmon of AMP, again responding to One Nation, said:

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask: what is the difference between the enterprise bargaining endorsed by the Industrial Relations Commission in October 1991 and his Government's latest proposal for workplace agreements outlined in One Nation?

—We will be announcing in due course and very soon the full detail of the amendments that we propose to make to the Industrial Relations Act. What the One Nation statement affirms is a statement I put down in the Senate in October last year that the Government will amend industrial law, where necessary, to accommodate and encourage workplace bargaining in this country. I believe that that comment was picked up and reflected in the unique way in which decisions in national wage cases are written. In the October national wage case decision, which shortly followed my ministerial statement, the Commission itself called on the Government to review sections 115 and 112 of the Industrial Relations Act to accommodate more workplace bargaining. What the Prime Minister said last Wednesday night reaffirmed that commitment and, indeed, strengthened it. There still needs to be consultation with some of the industrial partners on the details of what we propose. When that has been done, I will announce them.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister actually saying to us that, even though his Government has put in the One Nation statement an outline of workplace agreements, he does not know what they are? In fact, can one interpret that as being just a stunt?
—If one wished to engaged in pernicious misrepresentation, one could do that. But I am not saying—
—Let's get Bill Kelty in here to answer these industrial relations questions. He sets your policy.
—Order!
—Thank you, Mr President. Of course that would be a pernicious interpretation. It is one that I do not think would be worthy of Senator Crane.

PARA.TAB: But what is absolute and unequivocal is that the Government will be amending its industrial law to achieve the purpose of which I have spoken. It will be an amendment to our industrial law which will guarantee an ongoing role for the Industrial Relations Commission, unlike what Mr Howard is talking about under Liberal Party policy in which his party will undermine or remove the Commission from the field of industrial regulation. It will be an amendment which will guarantee the continuance and existence of awards of the Commission to protect workers in this country by providing minimum standards, unlike what the Opposition is proposing—to bypass the award system.

It will be an amendment which will contemplate the continuance of national wage cases to determine across the board wage adjustments for the wider community and particularly for those workers in poor bargaining positions where minimum wages need to be determined, unlike what Mr Howard is proposing—the abolition of national wage cases. It will be an amendment which will recognise the dynamic and important role of unions working with the Government in a cooperative relationship to achieve low levels of inflation in this country and higher productivity. It will be an amendment that recognises that role, not one which pulls on a full-scale industrial battle in this country and which knocks the economy off course—which is the sort of thing that the Opposition is proposing. The amendments will do all of those things and deliver workplace bargaining in an effective way in Australia that gives us a productivity surge in the economy as we come out of the recession.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the claim by the Melbourne Herald Sun recently that one in four people in Australia is on welfare? Can the Minister comment on this claim and can he say how these figures compare to the numbers on welfare in 1983?

—I suppose there are two ways of calculating the number of people on welfare. One could count all those who receive a payment from the Department of Social Security, and if one did one would get a figure over four million. But as Senator Crowley will know, everyone in this chamber has acknowledged that family payments are not and have never been considered to be welfare payments. Rather, they are payments which recognise the increased costs for families raising children. When one considers that about half the 4.5 million people Senator Crowley is talking about are in that category, the figures start to take on a bit more meaning.

PARA.TAB: Obviously that story was a pretty dreadful beat-up. While there may well be four million people getting some payment from the Department of Social Security, I would point out that the proportion of the labour force who are recipients of DSS payments has declined from 41.9 per cent in June 1983 to 35.5 per cent in June 1991. As a proportion of the population I think the interesting figure is that the number of DSS recipients has fallen from 19 per cent to 17.4 per cent. Although there has been a tremendous growth in the 1980s in our population and a 22 per cent growth in the same period in the labour force, there has been a fall in the number of those—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you compare it to 1980?

—The June 1991 figures are a pretty fair comparison. The reason that Senator Alston finds this uncomfortable is that when the Government came to office we inherited a totally untargeted social security system. No attempt had been made in the previous decade to do anything about fraud or abuse. Fortunately, during the 1980s and further into the 1990s this Government has spent a great deal of time and effort in doing just that and has done it with remarkable success. During that time I think that we have done it without creating in the community the kind of unrest that was created in those years before we got government because the targeting has always been done with fairness and equity in mind.

PARA.TAB: Over the life of this Government it is worth noting that payments for children in low income families have increased in real terms by 52 per cent if they are under 13 and by 121 per cent for teenage children. Payments to sole parents with between one and four children have increased by about 16 per cent or 24 per cent if one includes rental assistance. Unfortunately for Senator Alston and others, the list goes on and on.

The point is that the percentage of those in Australia who receive welfare payments has declined during the term of this Government as against the position we inherited. But what is more, the payments to those at the bottom end of the scale went up, and went up by very substantial amounts indeed. The Government has improved the real living standards of those who receive social security payments, at the same time making sure that increased assistance was targeted only to those who were in need.

I hope that those on the Opposition benches look long and hard at those figures. It might stop the kind of ignorant comment that we have seen even in here today. It may mean that people will start concentrating on what the system can deliver, not simply on the words. The words that have been delivered here today go a long way towards stretching the English language. When one listens to Senator Alston about the record of what happened from 1975 to 1983 as against 1983 to 1992, it is pathetic.

The truth is that those opposite did nothing, they cannot do anything and they do not like it when we show that we have done something. But what is even worse is that if people are on low incomes they will have to face Fightback! If they are on low incomes and have to face a consumption tax, they really will get hurt and will really start getting into trouble. It will not only be a case of their worrying about a billion dollar hole in the figures that Senator Alston was responsible for; they will have to come up against that cold, cruel, heartless regime that rips it out of their pockets and gives it to the rich.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to Australia's circumstances as a trading nation and draw the Minister's attention to the focus upon Australian trade policy, particularly measures for assistance provided to exports in the Prime Minister's economic statement of last week. In the light of these, how are refinements to policy designed to contribute to a further growth in Australian exports? Is this a priority? Is there reason for greater confidence for the future?

—A very central theme of the One Nation statement was the need to continue lifting our export performance. As all of us ought to know by now, for a trading nation such as Australia strong and sustained export growth is really the key to long term growth being achieved in output, employment and living standards. To accelerate export growth requires at least three interlocking sets of strategies by governments: first, getting the overall domestic climate of macro- and micro-economic reform policy right; secondly, getting better access to overseas markets; and, thirdly, through direct support of export promotion. I emphasise that all three of those policies are absolutely crucial.

PARA.TAB: Despite the recurring claims by some commentators, who ought to know better, and by some Opposition spokesmen, who manifestly do not—those people who seem unable to look beyond our commitment to the Uruguay Round—the truth of the matter is that our trade policy is not one dimensional; it is anything but that.

As to the overall economic climate, the One Nation statement is largely about maximising our competitiveness and about improving the micro-and macro-economic climate for business, for growth generally and for exports in particular. It is not just, as the Opposition spokesman on trade was heard to say the other day, the $41m that is earmarked for export promotion that is relevant in the One Nation statement. It is the whole $2.3 billion package and a very large proportion of it which is directed very immediately through its injection of cash into the area of infrastructure spending, through the commitment to ongoing, regulatory reform and other micro-economic reform, and through the tax incentives for investment, which will lower costs and boost our output and efficiency. All those dimensions are crucial.

Moreover, of course, it is a central element of our policy, as emphasised in the One Nation statement, to preserve the gains made in inflation. If one really wanted to destroy Australia's competitive climate internationally, one would go straight down the path of the Hewson consumption tax package, which is notoriously and conspicuously inflationary by contrast.

In that second policy area, the second government strategy, which is crucially relevant here, is to pursue better access to markets by removing inhibiting tariffs, and through other barriers. There are three dimensions to that kind of policy, not just one, as is so often asserted.One is the global dimension, through the Uruguay Round. Secondly, there is the regional dimension, through the establishment and pursuit of APEC. Thirdly, there is everything we are doing bilaterally with other countries in that trade policy access area.

The third element in the strategy—and this is the one that is focused upon most specifically in the One Nation package—is the question of direct support for export promotion activities. That is what we have achieved through increased funding for the export access program, which assists small and medium sized firms to export, with increased funding of $8m over the next three years, through a funding injection of $15m over the next three years to expand Austrade's international network, especially in the Asia Pacific region, through the $18m of extra funds injected into DIFF—the development and import finance facility—which boosts our exports, of course, of capital goods and services, and, finally, through the expanded export performance bond facility, which trebled to $150m, which helps Australian businesses win contracts for major overseas projects.

The Australian Government is very proud of the export performance record to date of this country. Export volumes have doubled since March 1983 and, despite the downturn in the global economy, export growth has accelerated over the past 2 years, conspicuously in the area of elaborately transformed manufactures. Export volumes rose by 7 per cent in 1989-90, by 13 per cent in 1990-91, and there has been a sustained increase in the ratio of our exports to GDP.

We are very pleased with the way in which we have already achieved a very dramatic growth in Australia's exports to North East Asia and South East Asia. The Bureau of Statistics figures released last week show that almost 60 per cent of Australia's exports of goods in the last six months went to Asia, an increase from the 53 per cent in earlier times.

As the Prime Minister said in the One Nation statement, we are confident that by 1994 we can achieve a $20 billion increase in our exports, of which the potential increase to Asia is $13 billion. So, compared to these kinds of commitments and expectations—

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to speak briefly to this Customs' report on the illegal entry of a vessel into Montague Sound earlier this year. I say at the outset that this is a very poor report. It exposes the Coastwatch system as a ramshackle and totally inadequate service.

PARA.TAB: Five minutes is a totally inadequate period in which to deal with what is an enormously important subject: the security of Australia from illegal immigrants, the import and export of prohibited goods and all the other things that the Coastwatch service is set up to prevent, in the civil regime, coming into or going out of this country.

I make a couple of general points at the outset. First of all, it is unfortunate that Customs gets the blame, by implication, because it conducted this inquiry. Customs has been managing the Coastwatch service for two or three years now. It took it over from one of the other Commonwealth departments, and it has been a very good manager of the service. The problem with the service is that the Government is not prepared to put enough money into it. Customs' part has really been quite commendable in seeing that, within those limited resources, Coastwatch operates as well as it can.

The second general point is that the members of the inquiry were all chosen from in-house. It is very difficult for them to be objective and I think that shows very clearly through the report. There is also a degree of naivety about the whole thing. I think the inquiry was very badly conducted and a lot of assumptions it made simply cannot be backed up.

I move very quickly through the report. The executive summary starts with the astonishing statement that Coastwatch failed to detect a target vessel illegally landing in Australia. On the next page the report says that the first intelligence report in July 1991 was of this vessel being in Jakarta and that six months later the vessel landed in Australia. It is interesting that those in the vessel actually saw a Coastwatch aircraft on 31 December. The report states that the aircraft had not been briefed on a possible vessel arriving at the time. Are we to presume, if Coastwatch aircraft are not told to expect an illegal ship, that the crews have their eyes in the cockpit or are reading or doing something like that?

The major part of the report is directed towards complaining about the shortages of intelligence information. The report hangs the failure to detect the vessel purely on the fact that there was not adequate intelligence available. I will come back to that in a minute. In the findings of the report, it becomes apparent that very little flying is actually done, even though the Coastwatch capabilities were expanded considerably under the new contract, in the areas that are at risk. In fact, the report says that the only flying that is done out to sea is on the approaches both to Darwin and to Broome because it is not thought likely that anyone would land in the Kimberley area where this ship came ashore. According to the report, that is really based on the experience of seven arrivals over the last two years. If that has been the pattern of the arrivals, a great degree of inflexibility in the planning and the approach of the Coastwatch service has developed.

Everything seems to turn on this lack of intelligence. There are a couple of points I make about that. First of all, if anyone has any knowledge at all of the Indonesian archipelago, they will know that there are thousands of islands and thousands of small craft there. If anyone thinks they can have an intelligence service which will tell which 30- or 40-foot boat will come to Australia with illegal immigrants, they are really whistling in the wind. It is quite impossible to have that degree of sophistication in an intelligence service.

Secondly, if we step up our countermeasures against these ships coming in, as we must—if these illegal immigrants, instead of coming in and advertising their presence and seeking to be detected in the way all these boat people have, operate in a covert way, no sort of intelligence service will know what is coming in. The answer is to change the system. We must have some degree of self-reliance with our own patrolling facilities to detect offshore, not inshore, when these ships arrive. It really does mean considerably more resources if we are to have an effective service.

One of the straw men the report puts up is the proposition that we can somehow or other have 100 per cent success against entry. That is not the point at all and it is never a point I have argued. What one has to have is a high probability of detection. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to address briefly this report by the Australian Customs Service Coastwatch on the investigation into the arrival of a suspect illegal entrant vessel carrying some 56 people into Montague Sound on the West Australian coast. I note that the investigation was carried out by an internal panel composed of members of Coastwatch and representatives of the client services. These client services have interests in fisheries, immigration, quarantine, customs, national parks and wildlife and Great Barrier Reef protection matters. I note with some concern that there does not seem to have been a representative of the Department of Defence and I shall return to that point.

PARA.TAB: I will pick out a number of items in the report without repeating the whole ambit of considerations which were canvassed by the previous speaker. I refer to a paragraph on page 6 which states that it would be impossible when investigating river mouths to do more than simply fly past them. It is clearly not possible, in the view of the Australian Customs Service, to investigate upstream whether anybody has entered a river. Doing so would reduce its capacity to carry out other supervision and surveillance activities. That in itself indicates the lack of resources, the thin coverage and indeed the whole ramshackle nature of Coastwatch as it currently is.

I also refer to the main problem that the investigation unit apparently found concerning the lack of definitive intelligence information. I believe that clearly shows that we are not at the moment capable of protecting our coastline, which should be our main defence focus. Following the end of the Cold War, the Australian Democrats believe that the focus of Australian defence strategy should be the protection of our coastline rather than an adherence to the old theory of forward defence which was maintained in our previous role as support forces to the United States global strategy.

The report's recommendations quite clearly indicate that we require a greater use of non-contract aircraft—in other words, more aircraft; that we should utilise more airfields in Western Australia; that we should change procedures and attitudes to a more goal directed point; that we should institute intelligence services capable of providing accurate and definitive information; and that we should increase liaison and cooperation—that the present system is simply not adequate.

It is clear that the present arrangements are simply not working and that we must ensure that our coastline is protected adequately. I believe that the only way to achieve that is to place current Coastwatch activities under the control of the defence forces and to ensure that the forward equipment purchasing program of the defence forces is changed to enable us to acquire the equipment and materiel that is required to protect our coastline, rather than indulge in the purchase of sabre rattling major items of defence equipment which have a long range capability which no longer has any relevance to our strategic considerations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to support what my colleague from Queensland Senator MacGibbon had to say about the Australian Customs Service report on the investigation into the illegal entry of a vessel into Montague Sound. My recollection of what happened over Christmas and my reading of the report seem to bear out the view that Coastwatch mostly watches the entrances to Darwin, Broome, Derby and Koolan Island rather than spending a great amount of time watching the open sea.

PARA.TAB: I do believe—if one can believe what the press had to say at the time—that some intelligence reports were coming through that the boat was on its way down. Obviously the people aboard it were heading for more civilised country. Anyone who has visited that area will certainly know what it is like—the vast expanses of beast lines and pastoral country with not too many people living there. I would say they came ashore for a brief period to have a look around and, as the report says, when they saw fires or smoke they thought there was civilisation inland and so they headed that way.

This seems to be borne out by the remarkably fit condition these people were in when rescued, after travelling the distance they had—and I do not know exactly how long they took to travel that distance. If they had not seen the fires and decided to take off inland, I presume they would have headed for Koolan Island, Broome, Derby or whatever.

Coastwatch should watch the isolated coast much more than it does. However, the rescuers and the organisers are to be commended. From what I remember of the report, it said that 56 people were lost in the bush over a number of days and were all rescued in the end without suffering any great harm. It was an incident that could have turned into a real disaster, even taking account of the shorter distance they travelled, but for the fact that there was rain in the area at that time of the year, which is rather unusual. The Wet usually starts much earlier, so they were lucky.

I know that the WA Police Force spent $12,500 in connection with the operation, or that is what it is claiming. I should like to mention also the station people who worked for the rescue of those people. They accommodated not only the 56 people who were rescued but also twice that number in rescuers and police, and they probably are not seeking recompense.

I believe that Coastwatch is doing a reasonable job, but those isolated areas have to be patrolled a lot more. As Senator MacGibbon has said, we cannot really rely on intelligence from the Indonesian islands about what is going on, although the media did say that there were some reports of those people being on their way down. Certainly we will need that type of intelligence to prevent a recurrence of illegal immigrants coming to Australia. Of course, it is important that the lives not only of the illegal immigrants but also of the people who go out rescuing them are not put in danger. I recommend that appropriate action be taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to make a few brief comments in support of my colleagues Senator MacGibbon and Senator Panizza with regard to Coastwatch. Coastwatch has been a major concern for Western Australians in particular for a long time, and Senator MacGibbon from Queensland shares that concern. Both our States have vast areas of coastline, which is an open door for people wishing to come into Australia. The incident earlier this year to which Senator Panizza was referring was particularly serious. It showed how easy it is for a group of people not only to break the coastline but also to get quite a long way inshore before being detected in any way, shape or form. What is concerning people from the Kimberley and the Pilbara, and other Australians, I might add, is the risk of disease to humans, livestock and wildlife, and how that can turn this country around from being a very safe and secure place.

PARA.TAB: I have been concerned for many years about the way in which the Government has been cost-cutting Coastwatch. That concern goes back many years to when Amman Aviation and Skywest Airlines were battling to try to get the contract for Coastwatch. It is not a case of blaming Coastwatch per se; it is a case of saying: where is the money coming from? Is it sufficient? Is that organisation underresourced, undermanned? The bottom line is the amount of finance that is being put towards Coastwatch to ensure that there is adequate protection of our coastlines all the way around northern Australia.

This requirement has, I fear, been put on the back-burner for many years. I do not think enough attention has been paid to the fact that we are talking about a very valuable part of our coastline. Because many diseases can enter along the coastline, why has not more attention been focused on those areas?

I cannot understand why earlier this year the Government kept saying that there had been a hint of intelligence passed on from other countries that this boat was on its way, when in fact it appeared that our own intelligence was inadequate to confirm or deny one way or the other what was happening. PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 27 February, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the closing part of the second reading debate on the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill. The purpose of the Bill is to allow the Commonwealth to approve shareholders' agreements, signed by the Commonwealth with New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, and Western Australia on 30 July last year, relating to the establishment of the National Rail Corporation.

PARA.TAB: The parties to the agreement agreed that a company would be established for the purpose of conducting interstate rail freight operations in Australia on a commercial basis, in accordance with principles compatible with those set out in the Heads of Government agreement of the National Rail Freight Corporation of 31 October 1990.

Those principles, very briefly, were that the company will operate on a strictly commercial basis, have access to the requisite sites, operate under labour agreements that reflect best international practice and productivity standards, and be able to attract activities where appropriate, to provide access to its network and facilities to public and private sector operators, and be able to provide services for the Government on a strictly commercial basis and not be in any way responsible for redundancies that might arise in rail authorities resulting from its formation and operation.

The Opposition supports those objectives of the National Rail Corporation. We recognise that there are a lot fine objectives in that, but we have great doubts as to whether the Government has the will and the ability to bring them about, particularly when the Government talks about the introduction of best international practices in productivity standards and labour agreements. For a government which has shown great reluctance to improve productivity—and the graphs of the performance of Australia in the last eight years that this Government has been in power show that pretty well everything else in the country has grown: unemployment, indebtedness, bank failures, commercial failures—productivity on an international level has been absolutely negligible, and stands in stark contrast with the achievements of other industrialised nations.

We hope the Government is serious about this expression of a wish to introduce best international practice in productivity standards. To bring that about, it really has to free up the labour market and get away from having a Minister such as Senator Cook who on every issue dances to the tune of the ACTU and the unions. Unless that is done, the real problem is that we will end up, as a consequence of this National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill, with a far worse situation for Australia than we have at present.What we have at present is not very good. No-one would claim that Australia's railways, collectively or individually, are models of efficiency and commercial success. I forget the amount they lose every year, but it probably runs into well in excess of $1 billion. They lose that amount because they are badly managed, and one of the key reasons for that is that labour relations within the unions—and the railway unions are extremely conservative—just have not moved with the times.

It is very important that we have an efficient national transport system. One cannot view a transport system by looking at the individual units and developing one of them. It is fair to say that 10 years ago we had a reasonably efficient air transport system in Australia. I do not think the same is true today. We need to develop the best, most efficient systems we can in road, rail, air and sea. There are certainly innate characteristics with each form of transport which make it the transport system of choice for certain goods and services.

Large bulk commodities that do not have any time pressure for delivery from one point to another are best moved by sea, provided the utilisation points are accessible to ports. Road transport certainly has the great advantage of flexibility. Roads lead to most parts of this country; the road system is highly developed. The road transport industry operates under enormous penalties. As Senator Panizza was telling me during Question Time, it pays 20 per cent sales tax on trucks and equipment, which stands in marked contrast with the sales tax reduction from 20 per cent to 15 per cent for cars announced in Mr Keating's statement last week. The industry pays an enormous amount in fuel excise and other imposts but, even so, it still survives.

It is interesting to look back historically at the way the sea trade on the coast of Australia has almost collapsed. Once upon a time sea trade was a big carrier for both passengers and freight. It is not so far back in history that we had a strong seaborne trade around Australia—probably up until the mid-1950s. We certainly had the large passenger liners—the Kanimbla, the Manunda, the Manoora and the Westralia—plying around the capital cities and up to Cairns. With the development of the tourist trade on an international basis, provided the work practices could be overcome, there would be a place for cruise liners of some size doing the Barrier Reef and north Queensland runs up the east coast of Australia again.

We also had a very strong coastal shipping trade working through the river ports and going up the east coast, where we have so many river ports, both in New South Wales and in Queensland. There was a very strong interstate trade. That was also killed off, and it was killed off through work practices—by the dominance of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia and the Seamen's Union demanding conditions of service that the industry simply could not support. But it was also killed off—and this is its relevance to this Bill—by the States' railways, which sought to get rid of what was a competitor, particularly in the form of intrastate coastal shipping.

I can remember in my own State of Queensland the way the Queensland railways would come to the clients of AUSN, Howard Smith and the other shipping companies operating on the coast and offer them rates for the transport of their goods up the Queensland coast that the shipping companies, even if they had efficient manning practices, simply could not meet. Once the ships went off the trade, the railways were free to set their own freight rates without any respect for competition.

Returning to the history of railways in Australia, since about 1850 we have been bedevilled by the fact that there has not been an overall view of running a rail system for the whole of Australia. The way we all came to get separate gauges for each State so that no State could pinch another State's rolling stock is well known and there is no point in going over what is now old history. The tragedy is that the lack of unification of the railways system has persisted, to our great economic disadvantage, well past the point by about 100 years that it should have. We have a need to run a standard gauge on all the lines in this country.

It is not the purpose of this Bill to canvass the need for the development of one standard permanent way system around Australia, beyond saying that, while it is a necessity, it needs a fair bit of thought as to how it will be funded. I am not putting the case that the Federal Government should fund 100 per cent of it, although I am conscious of the argument that there is a national advantage in such a system and that therefore the common interest justifies some taxpayer support for that system. An extension of that argument is that if it is going to be for the national good, as I believe it is, and the development of the country, I do not see why one generation should pay for it in two or three decades when it is an asset the country will possess and derive benefit from over many years.

Apart from the lack of standard gauge in the railway system, the conservatism of the railway unions has been a problem. They have been interested in preserving their jobs without taking any cognisance of how they operate in those jobs. They have been supported in that, in the main, by complacent State governments. State governments have not been too concerned about the enormous losses the railways have made over all the time they have owned them, and that has led to a reluctance to see railways as systems to which modern technology could be applied.

Two or three years ago I went to Rockwell Collins at Cedar Rapids. Rockwell Collins is one of the world leaders in avionics and electronic systems principally for aviation and some marine use, but it has also developed an advanced electronic control system for the operation of railways. That system virtually transfers aircraft-type technology into locomotive engine cabins. It not only gives a totally different and far more efficient environment for the operation of train crews, leading to big increases in safety, ease of operation and reduction in manning, but also applies to the whole of the control system for the regulation of rail traffic on lines, the communications systems of trains in transit and so on. It is a very comprehensive system. It also has simulators similar to aircraft simulators so that locomotive drivers can be trained within a workshop or laboratory in operational techniques, safety procedures and all the rest of it.

I looked at this and my first reaction, given the fact that it has not been a high technology industry, was to ask the company whether locomotive drivers in their forties, fifties and older, who may even have started with steam trains in the United States, could be re-educated and taught modern practices. The company representatives said that one of the great surprises of the system was that they found that train crews converted successfully and enthusiastically to these new practices.

At the end of the day, the introduction of systems such as this significantly improves productivity, but I suggest that we would look in vain to see any State government, or even the National Rail Authority, moving in these directions within Australia. It is one of the things that we have to do if we are to have a profitable rail system. We must have a system which does not make anywhere near the present losses.

I have already referred to the business of best practice in labour relations and I will not canvass that. On the subject of profitability of the railway lines, I would like to refer to my own State of Queensland. Probably the only State railway which makes a nominal profit is Queensland Railways, but it does that through grossly unfair practices. Queensland Railways derives its profit from quite extortionate charges on the captive audience it has in the Bowen Basin with its coalfields. The irony of the situation is that the mines contributed pretty well 100 per cent to the cost of building that rail line and now, for the privilege of running on it, pay quite extortionate charges to the State Government which go towards covering all the other inefficiencies within the State Rail.

The consequences of that are several. First, it means that the State Government is under very little pressure to improve the gross inefficiencies in the rest of the services in the State. Secondly, those taxes—which is what they are; they are not a charge for a service, they are a straight out tax, a concealed tax, on the coal industry—are making the retention of export markets, let alone the acquisition of new markets, very difficult. The rail cost has to be added to the cost of coal.

Whilst I noted with pleasure that this Government picked up the proposition of the Liberal Party and the National Party that in government we would abolish the coal export levy—which was another iniquitous tax—and got rid of the coal export levy, it is doing nothing about talking to its colleagues in the Labor Government in Queensland to get them to set a fair and reasonable charge for rail freights on the Queensland fields.

I hope that the Government can attain the objectives that it has listed in this Bill. It will certainly to need a great deal more determination than it has shown at any time in the previous eight years of government to take on the unions and come up with efficient work practices, and I hope it does not walk away from its responsibilities in that regard. As I said earlier, if the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill does not work in the way it is intended to, Australia will be very much worse off, losing many more billions of dollars on an inefficient rail service. It is vital that the Government has the will and the determination to proceed down the path that it has outlined and take it to a successful conclusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill 1991. I have had a long interest in rail in South Australia mainly because of the role of Australian National in South Australia. It is a very important industry. Australian National is still either the third or fourth biggest employer of labour in South Australia of any public or private sector industry. It has a considerable influence on the economic well-being of South Australia.

PARA.TAB: Since Australian National was created in 1975, when the Whitlam Government reached agreement with the Dunstan State Labor Government to take over the State rail, AN in South Australia has done an excellent job in building up a commercially viable freight organisation that has substantially improved productivity and has been run efficiently with good management. In my view, Australian National is a model that every other State rail system in Australia could follow with success.

Australian National also looks after the rail system in Tasmania. At the same time as South Australian Rail was taken over by the Commonwealth, the Tasmanian State Rail was taken over. Again, similar significant improvements in the running of Tasrail have occurred. All the evidence is there that Australian National, the rail system owned by the Commonwealth, has proved itself to be the best rail system in Australia.

It has had to make a number of very tough decisions over the last 17 years since its establishment. For example, when it took over the South Australian rail system and combined it with the old Commonwealth Railways which were operating in South Australia, the total number employed was close to 13,000; it is now under 6,000. That has obviously been a significant reduction. All of it was done by attrition and voluntary redundancies and without creating any long term industrial disputes. It is a credit to both the trade unions involved and to the management that that reduction in the work force has been achieved while Australian National has been able to improve its productivity.

Some other changes came about in that period because of advanced technology. For example, the replacement of wooden sleepers by concrete sleepers on much of the east-west railway line that Australian National controls through South Australia has substantially reduced the number of fettlers employed along the line from probably close to 1,000 to now only a couple of hundred. There will be further reductions in the future.

Improved communication systems using new technology on that rail system have also meant that jobs have gone. Using bigger, more powerful and longer trains and double stacking of containers have meant job losses, but there has also been a significant improvement in productivity. It has meant that over the last decade or more the east-west railway freight line, from Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide to Perth, has broken even. It seems to me that Australian National in particular has to be given considerable credit.

I suppose most of us who are interested in rail transport in Australia have made many speeches about the history in Australia of the development of rail. It has led to each State having a separate rail system, with the madness of different gauges from the last century when petty State parochialism meant that we ended up with three different railway gauges. That is still the main problem we are trying to overcome as far as running a national system of rail is concerned.

We also must be the only country of 17 million people—even though spread across a very large continent—that has five rail systems operating with five separate managements which arbitrarily stop at State boundaries. It has meant that since Federation there has never been any great effort made to overcome the parochialism of the nineteenth century and the structure of the way rail was operated. When we look at the maps of the various States we see railway lines going out from each of the capital cities like spokes. Before the turn of the century every rural and regional community wanted to have a train line reaching it because that meant it could transport its produce and its people to and from the capital city. It also meant jobs in the local town.

Those were the days when we relied on ox carts and horse transport to shift produce at the rate of about 20 or 25 miles a day. So the introduction of train lines into country areas was a transport revolution. But, as I said, because of the stupidity of colonial administrators in adopting different rail gauges, we have never had the benefit of a national rail system. However, through the National Rail Corporation, it seems that there is some hope that instead of having five or six rail systems operating in Australia, by the beginning of next century we might be down to only one or two, and certainly one national organisation for interstate freight.

This agreement came about as a result of discussion and negotiations last year between the Federal Government and the various States that are involved. In general, like most reasonable people, I obviously support the concept of a National Rail Corporation. But there are a number of aspects about it that cause me concern. The first one is that to reach agreement with the States, the Commonwealth had to agree that no matter how much equity or financial resources it put into the National Rail Corporation it could not get more than 49 per cent of the vote on the board of the Corporation, and also it could not have a majority of board members. I believe that that is an unacceptable outcome.

It would be very strange indeed if a majority shareholder of any company in the world who is contributing, as in this case, hundreds of millions of dollars would be precluded for at least the first five years from having any more than 49 per cent of the voting rights around the board room table. I cannot imagine any other shareholder in a similar venture anywhere else in the world, let alone Australia, saying, `We will put 80 per cent of the money in, but those interests putting in less than 50 per cent are going to end up with more than 50 per cent of the vote'. I do not think that is a sensible outcome. In the negotiations the States would not agree to any other arrangement because they were very much afraid that the Commonwealth, via AN, would dominate the running of the National Rail Corporation.

There has been too much petty parochialism by States trying to protect their patches, whether through management of the State rail system, through State governments, or through various trade unions. There has always been a very strong protection of States rights in the running of rail. I think that has cost Australia dearly.

Since this Bill was introduced into the Parliament, the Prime Minister has brought down the One Nation statement which indicated that over the next four years there will be nearly $500m made available to upgrade the rail system around Australia. I do not think anyone would object to that money being spent. It has been greatly welcomed by the people in the transport industry and the rail industry. I am very pleased to see the conditions the Prime Minister has put on the $400m-plus. At page 98 of the One Nation document, the following statement is made:

SPEECH.PARA: In order that the Government can be assured that this additional investment in rail is used to full effect, several conditions will need to be met before funds will be released. These conditions require
. firm commitments from the unions to support a "greenfields" NRC, enterprise award incorporating labour arrangements which are already set out in the NRC Shareholders' Agreement

. firm commitments from State governments to accelerate the process of reform in their rail systems, including the early adoption of relevant recommendations from the Industry Commission's 1991 Report on the Rail Industry
. where additional rail investment is channelled through the States, that
—the NRC must agree to design and standards to apply before contracts are let
—all contracts are to be subject to competitive bidding

—on completion of each project, the upgraded asset is to be managed and maintained to the standards specified by the NRC, and appropriate recognition given to the Commonwealth's equity in the Corporation for assets that become part of the NRC network

I believe that the last point, in particular, starts to address the concern I have expressed about the original agreement—that the $400m the Commonwealth is putting in by way of equity, as outlined in this statement, should be reflected in the voting strength of the National Rail Corporation.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister for Shipping and Aviation (Senator Collins), when responding to the second reading debate, whether he would be able, even at this early stage, to give indications to the Senate of what stage negotiations are at with changing the articles of incorporation to ensure that the Commonwealth does get a commensurate voting strength to the amount of equity it is putting in. When we add AN's assets and the $400m outlined in the One Nation statement, we are looking at a Commonwealth contribution of probably somewhere around 70 per cent plus. It would be irresponsible of the Australian Government and the Parliament to allow a situation in which its equity contribution to an organisation that it has established is not reflected in voting rights. I hope that the Minister, in response to the second reading debate or at the committee stage, can give some indication to the Senate of where we are at with those negotiations on voting rights.

In relation to the future of the National Rail Corporation, some tough decisions will be taken which will be unpopular in various parts of Australia. I notice that, in my own State of South Australia, the standardisation of the Adelaide-Melbourne railway line will mean that a number of broad gauge railway lines will no longer have a connection to Adelaide. I do not think a third rail will be put down the middle of the broad gauge track. So the Bordertown-Mt Gambier railway line will no longer be connected to Adelaide. I think most of the rail lines in the Murray-Mallee, which mainly carry wheat, will also be left broad gauge and will not have a connection to Adelaide. Although I have read the One Nation document, I still cannot find the detail on that. Perhaps the Minister, in response to the second reading debate, can also give us some indication on that matter. If those train lines are left broad gauge, there is no doubt that in a short period they will be under threat of complete closure.

I note that the One Nation statement indicates that the Commonwealth has reached agreement with the State Government of South Australia that the passenger service between Adelaide and Mt Gambier will now cease. The State Government has agreed not to go to court or the tribunal in relation to this matter. I also have to say that one does not have to be a genius to realise that the broad gauge train lines in parts of South Australia that will be left after standardisation will be a bit like dags on the end of a sheep. When announcements are made some time in the intermediate future that those lines will probably be closed completely, there will be quite a strong community reaction. That matter will have to be dealt with. We will have to explain to people that the services that may be lost—even at freight level, let alone passenger level—can be made up in some other way.

I hope, of course, that it would be possible for the Bordertown-Mount Gambier line to be standardised and for the present broad gauge line to be converted to standard gauge by the technique of bringing the rail in from five feet three inches to four feet eight and a half inches. Some people may argue that that would be too costly and that there would not be a cost-benefit return. But that will be a major issue for my own State. It will certainly be an issue in western Victoria where there is a major broad gauge system running from Mildura through Horsham down to Portland, as well as other ancillary lines, all of which run the risk of being dismembered from the standard gauge system—again leading to pressure for them to be closed. That will be a major issue in Victoria as it is in South Australia and again will have to be addressed by the National Rail Corporation and various governments.

Even though those are difficult problems, we should not be deflected from the main aim of establishing a national rail freight corporation with one management system across Australia. I argue very strongly that it must be a management that reflects the equity contribution of the various shareholders. I must say that I do not trust State governments with running rail systems. The track record in Australia of State governments running rail systems, particularly in the eastern States, has been a never ending list of disasters. Billions of dollars have been lost because governments—I am not picking out Labor or Liberal; it applies to all State governments—have never been willing to make the tough decisions about management to restructure their rail in accordance with modern requirements.

At times I have made myself unpopular with some sections of the rail unions in the eastern States by pointing that out. I do not believe that the rail systems of New South Wales or Victoria should be run as a social welfare system. If there are problems with redundancy and with having to reduce labour, they should be dealt with in a properly organised restructuring package whereby appropriate redundancies are paid commensurate with people's service. One does not throw people out on the scrap heap. But, conversely, one cannot expect the taxpayers to go on funding endlessly, as if into a big black hole, the losses of the State rail systems of New South Wales and Victoria, because in the end they will destroy the Budgets of both those States.

At the end of last year I was involved with reaching an agreement in South Australia between the Federal Government, AN and the unions over the redundancy package paid there when AN said that it needed to reduce labour by another 1,500 positions over a four- or five-year period. After some robust—to say the least—discussions and negotiations, agreement was reached as a special one-off package. As a result, it appears that there will be no forced redundancies; people will take the package and leave voluntarily. I believe that that has been a very successful outcome.

I do not think New South Wales and Victoria have acted wisely in the past. They have responded to political pressure to maintain rail systems in areas where clearly they are not economic. I have to agree that I, like other politicians from time to time, will lobby hard when I have constituents in a particular area asking for a rail service to be maintained and a railway station to remain open. We have all been in a sense guilty of that when it may not have been in the long term economic interest of the rail system for it to remain a commercial operation. Rail should be run as a commercial operation. If the community wants a special service provided, that should be transparently identified and subsidised in a specific way in the Budget, provided out of taxpayers' revenue, but in such a way that it is seen by everybody. It should not be done with just a global figure so that it is hidden, because in the end it is the good old taxpayers who pay for it.

I hope that the National Rail Corporation does not fall for what I would call the pea and thimble trick of trying to pick up the losses and inefficiencies of the system in New South Wales and Victoria, but I am suspicious still that attempts will be made by both those State governments and their rail systems to cross-subsidise some of the loss areas in their own States from the profitable area that is coming to the National Rail Corporation from the east-west freight system.

I see Senator Panizza sitting on the other side of the chamber. He is a Western Australian. Westrail is the other rail system in Australia that should be congratulated on the efforts it has made to upgrade itself to make a profit on interstate freight. I think that South Australians and Western Australians should be very wary to ensure that the profit making on the east-west freight line is not used to subsidise the present enormous losses on the Melbourne-Sydney-Brisbane line. Those losses are made because the train line is not up to standard. We have all heard it before; there are too many bends and too many hills and it is a slow trip. I understand from some people that the train now takes longer to get from Sydney to Melbourne than it did when the line was first built many, many years ago. I know that the train on part of the broad gauge line between Adelaide and Melbourne certainly goes slower than it did in 1880 when the train line was built because the track has not been kept at the level that it should have been. That was due to the problem of reaching agreement between State and Federal governments about who was responsible for paying what.

I suppose ultimately—some time in the next 10 or 15 years—Australians may be big enough to forget petty parochial State interests and end up with one rail system in this country with one management. When we get that I think we will be able to tackle an issue that I feel strongly about; that is, the building of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway line. I have to agree that it is very hard at the moment to say, in a cost-benefit analysis, that the line can pay for itself. But I think there are certain projects in Australia from time to time where one has to take a partial leap of faith to build the thing first in the belief that it is a national development issue. I certainly do not believe in the cargo cult of building a dam on every river in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Kimberley pipeline?

—On that matter I agree with my colleague Senator Walsh, who believes that one of the most stupidly fantastic ideas ever put up in Australia is the Kimberley water pipeline. We would be better off shipping icebergs from Antarctica and melting them in Perth than we would be building a pipeline from the Kimberleys. It would be the dearest water in the world. We might be better off giving everyone a gold bar rather than charge them for the cost per litre of getting the water from the Kimberleys to Perth. It is those sorts of projects of which we have to be wary.

PARA.TAB: I think the Alice Springs-Darwin train line can in the longer run be justified. If we get the system in the south operating properly—in particular, if we get the freight system in the southern States working well—I think the justification for the Alice Springs-Darwin line gets stronger, with a major modern container port to be built near Darwin and connected to the rail system using a standard gauge. We could cut the time for freight coming into southern Australia from South East Asia by five or six days by having a land bridge across Australia. But it would require a very efficient train system, a very efficient container port in Darwin, and fast freight trains operating at speeds of 110 to 140 kilometres per hour on a very good track. That would mean that we would save probably a week's shipping time in getting goods in both directions between Asia and the southern States.

Importers and exporters would find that that time saving reduced their costs. That is good micro-economic reform. However, there is no doubt that the higher priority in the short term is to get the southern system working properly. I think one could then justify the Alice Springs-Darwin line with a modern container port. As an article of faith I would say that, but I do not think that it is faith in the blind sense of pie in the sky.

Those of us who have been aficionados of trains and rail in Australia for a long time have had a pretty bleak period over the past 20 or 30 years. Despite some of my misgivings about the technical structure of the board of the National Rail Corporation and with the statement last week, for the first time since the great train building periods of the last century Australia is getting back into trains in a big way. That is to be welcomed. We will end up with an efficient freight system for long haul freight that will make Australia a more competitive place. I think also it will make Australians, as the document says, one nation, accepting the fact that one cannot run rail as five separate systems which ought to be run nationally.

I have often wondered how one would run Australian Airlines or Ansett on the basis that when their aircraft crossed the State border there had to be a change of crew or that there were different booking systems. I have had plenty of examples given to me whereby freight and passengers have not been maximised in the system because different State rail systems have incompatible computer booking systems. I have been told, `You are on your own once you leave New South Wales because the Victorian system does not have a compatible computer system for monitoring the containers'.

I conclude by reciting what some people say is an hilarious story. If it were not so sad it would be funny. It is about the problem of having a number of different rail systems. Some two or three years ago, I asked representatives from General Motors in South Australia why they did not use rail to send their new cars to Sydney. The transport officer said, `We did try a year ago. We loaded up a train full of brand new Holden cars to go to Sydney, all pre-ordered, all ready to go to the dealers. People had paid their deposit. We put the cars on the train in Adelaide with AN and off it went. Three days later we started getting phone calls from dealers in Sydney saying, "Where are the cars?". We made an inquiry of AN, which said, "No, no. The train got to Broken Hill. We handed it over to State Rail of New South Wales". We rang up State Rail of New South Wales and asked, "Where are the cars?". It said, "They have been delivered. You have made some mistake". This went on for some days. After some days, State Rail of New South Wales had to admit that it had lost the train, it could not find a whole train which was loaded down with probably $1m worth of cars. Several more days went by and it finally found the train sitting in a siding, I understand, somewhere near the Menindee Lake by the River Darling.

That is the rail system we have at the moment. One just does not lose an occasional suitcase or even a container; the whole bloody train got lost. That is why General Motors went back to using trucks.

Per unit, that is a much more expensive way of getting cars to Sydney, but in the long run it was a decision it was forced to make because of the inefficiencies of having five different rail systems. I hope that before this decade is out State parochialism has gone and we have a decent rail system based on the beginnings of what we have before us here in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill 1991, I am pleased to follow Senator Schacht, particularly since he acknowledged and commented upon the long awaited Alice Springs to Darwin rail link. I believe that Senator Schacht's contribution to this debate is the first public statement by a Labor politician that goes down that route and certainly acknowledges that area of importance. I only hope that Senator Schacht does not feel that he will be subject to accusations of heresy by his waterfront unions in Melbourne and Sydney and some of the other interstate rail system unions.

PARA.TAB: If ever there was an opportunity for us to link South Australia and the adjoining parts of Australia with South and North East Asia through a rail connection from Alice Springs to Darwin, now is definitely the time. The proposal to extend Australia's standard gauge rail system by completing the national rail network between Darwin and Alice Springs has been an ongoing proposal since 1911 when it was a legislative promise of the Federal Parliament; it has not yet been honoured.
