There are many reasons why the concept of a railway from Alice Springs to Darwin and a new modern port infrastructure at Darwin, as Senator Schacht has just stated very correctly—known more recently as the integrated transport system—should go ahead. The most important of these is the fact that the world's fastest growing economies lie to Australia's north: Korea, Taiwan, Japan and Indonesia.
In his 1989 report entitled `Australia and the North East Asian Ascendancy', Professor Ross Garnaut wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's economic success in utilising opportunities associated with North East Asian economic growth is of fundamental importance to long-term economic success, and of substantial importance politically and culturally as well.
Relations with North East Asia are in order of magnitude more important to economic development in Australia than are relations with any other region.

Last week we saw the tabling of the report by the North East Asia Analytical Unit within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade entitled `Australia and North East Asia in the 1990s: Accelerating Change' in which the outlook for exports is referred to. It says:

North East Asia is expected to make the largest contribution of any region to Australia's export growth over the next five years. Export targets developed by Austrade suggest the possibility of gains of the order of A$10 billion Australian (in 1989 dollars) over 1989-1994.

The Northern Territory is undoubtedly very well placed to take advantage of these markets due to its proximity to Asia and through the establishment of trade agreements such as the recent trade memorandum signed by the Northern Territory Government and the Indonesian Government. If such reports are focusing Australia's attention on Asia and trading links with the region, then we as a nation should be looking at transport infrastructure that is commercially viable.

PARA.TAB: An integrated transport system cannot work without national commitment to the project. Again, I think it is important to stress that what we are looking for from all sides of the Parliament is a commitment to the project. It cannot work unless all Australians want it to work. It is fine for me, Senator Schacht and others to stand here and give a commitment in that regard, but it must be a commitment of political parties and of major organisations.

It is not only a project designed to benefit the Northern Territory. It is a project that will benefit all of Australia as we reduce our reliance on traditional trading partners in Europe and America and rightfully seek to forge new economic ties with the countries to our north. The proposal to build the north-south railway has been on the drawing board in one form or another since 1911 when the Commonwealth took over control from South Australia of the Northern Territory. As I said, there was a legislative promise and commitment at that time to this important project. A number of more recent feasibility studies have been increasingly positive with regard to both the construction and operation of the railway project.

I would have hoped that Senator Collins, both as a senator for the Northern Territory and as a Minister in the transport portfolio, would have been in this chamber to back up the comments of Senator Schacht in this important area. I suspect that, apart from someone like Senator Schacht who is prepared to speak out, we will not see many Labor politicians taking this bold stance or view because the waterfront unions of Sydney and Melbourne and the rail unions of southern Australia would not want to see the successful completion of such an important land bridge that would certainly change and alter their operations but which we should also be doing as part of all of the reforms that are so necessary in transport in Australia.

An integrated transport system would undoubtedly generate significant externalities which will provide long term benefits to Australia. There will be immediate benefits during the construction stage which will be distributed across a range of industries supplying labour and materials to the project. A completed north-south rail link will provide benefits to other rail systems and, in particular, the National Rail Corporation through increased freight movements. Providing rail services where none currently exist will substantially reduce maintenance costs and accidents on existing roads in Australia. The availability of rail transport could contribute to the development of other projects such as mineral resources.

At present, much of our international trade is carried on foreign ships. As Senator Schacht acknowledged in his statements, the additional travel time to take things to the waterfronts and then have them serviced across the wharves is a major area that needs change in Australia. The environmental impact of running one train as opposed to many trucks will be significantly less. Importantly and not least, even though it is last on my list, there will be defence preparedness and flexibility. I note, Madam Acting Deputy President Bjelke-Petersen, that today in Question Time you raised the matter of the Government's commitment to the projects it is putting forward in the One Nation proposal and the fact that that commitment is just not there, particularly in the areas that would relate transport and defence issues.

In the light of this benefit relating to defence preparedness, I point out that I have been interested in the benefits of defence forces based in northern Australia, particularly in relation to the north-south railway. During the 1990-91 Senate Estimates committee hearings, I asked questions of the Department of Defence about the Department's long term commitment to the Alice Springs to Darwin railway. The Department responded in the following way:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department recognises the undoubted benefits to Defence interests that would accrue from the construction of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway but it is not in a position to contribute funding for such an endeavour.
My response to this answer by the Department was this:
I think the acknowledgment by Defence of the undoubted benefits is very important to the long term planning of that transport route.

Given the current state of the economy and the attention national infrastructure programs have received in recent months, particularly in the coalition's Fightback proposals and in the Federal Government's statement of commitment and programming last week called One Nation, I believe that the time is now right for the Federal Government to review the Alice Springs to Darwin railway project as a national priority.

PARA.TAB: I must express disappointment that last week's statement by the Labor Party, One Nation, did not go anywhere in this regard. The map that appears on page 97 of the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of 26 February outlines the additional rail funding for all Australia. Some 12 or 14 projects are identified, but there is not one item of expenditure north of the Brisbane line. Even though the rail system is extended up to Cairns, there is no identification of the Alice Springs to Darwin railway; the map stops the rail connection at Alice Springs. There is not one mention in One Nation anywhere of any commitment to a project to extend the land bridge between Alice Springs and Darwin. There are many fine words and many other projects are mentioned, but most of these projects occur in that axis between Newcastle and Geelong and are conveniently located in Labor electorates or very close marginal seats. That point needs attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Northern Territory is a Labor electorate.
—Yes. That is one of the points I am making.
—Well, it goes against the point you are making.

—Fiddlesticks! Why did the Government not state that? Why has the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications, Warren Snowdon, not been able to achieve any form of commitment to such an important project? I am not denying that each and every one of the projects outlined has some significance, but I would have thought that more attention would be given to this project in the Northern Territory, given its importance and the more recent discussion in this area.

PARA.TAB: One Nation does address a number of issues relating to land transport and rail and road programs, just as Fightback! does. The Labor Government is committed to introducing non-deductible, non-assessable bonds for the funding of future capital works projects, but it is interesting to note that the funding of those projects does not start for several financial years. The coalition's Fightback proposal gives a major commitment to re-examining the tax rules for large infrastructure projects which would encompass—and specifically encompass in the documentation of Fightback!—the Alice Springs to Darwin railway.

Associated with any debate on the issue of rail are important points relating to transport and freight costs, which we must always address. In this respect, it is important to note that the coalition's proposals specifically look at the abolition of the petroleum products excise, including diesel and avgas. But in One Nation there is not one mention of the abolition of petroleum products excise and the resulting savings that would cascade and compound throughout Australia in that important area relating to transport and freight costs.

What about the removal of payroll tax, which is specifically addressed in the coalition's Fightback proposals? There is not one mention of that in last week's documentation relating to the Labor Party's proposals for one nation.

If Australia is to gain the confidence of investors, particularly our Asian neighbours, the north-south railway must be recognised as a project of national importance and as an integral part of Australia's future trade performance. Given the significant points associated with the proposal and the fact that existing institutional arrangements do not adequately provide for such development, there is a clear rationale for some degree of government involvement. I am pleased to see that the Northern Territory Government has taken the initiative for such an important project, and is well and truly running with the ball as a matter of major importance, major debate and financial commitment.

It is clear that Australia's long term strategic interests are to pursue closer trading links with our neighbouring countries in which infrastructure needs to be developed to serve such trading links. The north-south railway would provide the Northern Territory and northern Australia with access to transport infrastructure that most Australians take for granted. Such a proposal would create the potential for expanded national economic activity and the strengthening of ties with neighbouring Asian economies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are currently debating the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill 1991. Rail in this country has long been a cause of much debate—debate between the States and the Federal Government over control and debate within the community as to the efficiency of the rail system of this nation.

PARA.TAB: Over the past 20 years, people in government have tried to address some of the obvious problems with the rail system as it stands. However, at this moment, they stand divided. Last week some of the most significant changes in rail history were announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). As with the National Rail Corporation, these changes will address some of the obvious problems we face in relation to our railways.

The Bill before us, combined with the rail elements of the One Nation statement, will revolutionise the transport system of our great country. Australia is a nation with a definite need for a comprehensive, united rail system. Ever since white settlement began we have built up our rail infrastructure. At one point rail was the major mode of interstate travel and freight, but today it has declined significantly. Certainly people do not want to travel by train if they need to get somewhere quickly. Obviously at this point, in the short term train commuting will not be preferred by most Australians. However, many people will use trains for travelling as the network is built up under this Government.

I see the major initiatives for rail travel as being in the area of freight transportation. The rail system of this country will be improved so significantly that the most obvious and cheapest way to transport goods will be by rail. Australian National has consistently made profits through its freight operations, proving that money can be made in the rail sector. In the 1990-91 financial year, Australian National made a $9.7m profit in its freight operations. In fact, AN even made a sizeable profit on passenger services last year. The National Rail Corporation will build on this AN experience and provide Australian industry with the method of transport I am sure it would most prefer—efficient rail. To achieve this, freight costs must be reduced, business must be encouraged to use our railways and, therefore, our rail system must be revamped.

The concept of a national rail system has been discussed for a long time. Indeed, the complex web of colonial rail authorities would obviously have been inefficient from the very start of the Commonwealth. By the 1970s, serious discussion was taking place at a senior level to encourage the development of a national rail system under Federal jurisdiction. Unfortunately, because of the parochial attitude of most Australian States at the time, the plan was unable to go ahead. The result of negotiations was a merger between South Australian, Tasmanian and Commonwealth rail bodies to establish Australian National. This was a very positive step towards achieving a more efficient system, even though the two participating States could not link their rail systems across Bass Strait. In the latter 1980s when rail infrastructure was again discussed and a Federal rail system mooted, we were able to look at the situation again to try to achieve a more efficient system for this country.

There is widespread support for the establishment of a freight system that is competitive and based on rail. If a common authority to oversee such a system were put in place and the infrastructure were upgraded to ensure that it would be compatible with the national network, and if good industrial relations practices took place within the network, then there would be absolutely no reason why our rail system could not be competitive. The key to achieving this is an agreement between the Federal Government and the States. The National Rail Corporation Bill seeks to establish the aforementioned ideal rail freight system by establishing such an agreement. With the agreement being cemented into individual States' legislation and with each party holding shares, there is little doubt that the project will work. The National Rail Corporation is an independent venture with commercial interests at heart. This is, therefore, a very sound investment for the parties involved.

I truly believe that the increased use of rail transport will no doubt lead to increased safety on our roads. The number of accidents that are caused because of road infrastructure and human error is horrific. The Government cannot continually renew this infrastructure when there is a rail network in existence. The people of Australia realise the significance of rail in reducing the strain on our major highways. I sympathise with the road transport workers and operators who have worked very hard to establish their businesses and capture interstate markets, but the safety of the Australian people is best served by an enhanced rail freight system.

The establishment of the NRC does not mean that it will be a monopoly freight hauler in this country, as it will clearly compete with road transport. In fact, the Industry Commission Rail Transport report, volume one, makes the following important point about competition in freight services:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission is of the view that the NRC must not merely transform the current several inefficient monopolies into a single efficient monopoly; the NRC should not be given the sole licence to operate interstate freight. Contestability in interstate freight services must exist. The Commission is concerned that the NRC not be allowed to restrict access by other operators to the rail infrastructure or interstate freight market.

The Industry Commission's view has certainly been taken into account in the Bill before us. It does not seek to restrict competition but welcomes it. I believe that rail will be able to provide the more efficient service with the infrastructure and established services to cope with the demands placed upon it. The future of the road transport industry lies with filling in the gaps and networking in the rail system where it cannot compete.

PARA.TAB: Around the world within different continents and regional trading blocs there has been a trend to establish the type of uniform network that we are establishing today. In Europe it was decided that by next year all rail systems in the European Community would have access to all rail infrastructure. While there could be only one viable rail operator in Australia, this European experience does illustrate the concept of independent management of train and freight services. Rather than the owner of the tracks controlling the operations of the rolling stock and commercial activities, it is in separate hands. The NRC to a great extent will operate in this way. The infrastructure owners, of course, will be a party to the NRC agreement.

As a South Australian, I have been proud to see the advancement of Australian National over the past 15 years. With its operations based in Adelaide, it has shown the way to profits in our rail system. I am glad that the most important part of the National Rail Corporation, the national operations centre, will be based in Adelaide.

The National Rail Corporation is an exciting and important venture for this Government and this nation. It offers a chance for real competition in this nation's internal freight system. It will lead to more competitive industries as they will have less of a freight cost burden. It will also reduce the level of road transport, not through restrictive means but through good, honest competition. Unlike the Opposition, we believe in allowing competition rather than just helping our mates out. The NRC will continue the good work of Australian National in terms of freight transportation. In association with the rail and port reforms announced by the Prime Minister, it will lead to one of the best rail systems in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the National Rail Corporation Bill is, if not the most important Bill we will introduce in this session of Parliament, certainly a very important one. It gives expression in the area of transport to the One Nation plan, as outlined by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to look at the history of rail and note that it actually opened up this country, as it did America—although, of course, the railways were government owned in Australia rather than privately owned as in America, where real estate deals were very much involved in the way those railway systems developed. When one considers the disagreement between New South Wales and Victoria resulting in two different gauges being developed, one wonders how rail ever survived at all.

However, survive it did and the systems were gradually built. Rail at that time was seen to be very efficient compared with, say, the bullock trains and the horse-drawn wagons that used to take produce from the rural areas to the ports; and even more efficient than motor transport in the very early days. However, we have had a situation where for a number of reasons rail was seen to be inefficient when compared with modern transport systems on the roads. Also, in rail there was not what one would term `the best work culture possible'. I do not mean work culture in terms only of trade unionists and their attitudes and thoughts about job security. I mean work culture in terms of very bad management—shocking management—in the way it planned and the way it handled and worked with its people who did the hands-on work.

One must consider the whole picture of transport—an integrated transport system including rail, sea, air and road. If rail were suddenly to become a great deal more efficient, I do not believe all the people who are involved in transporting by road should fall by the wayside. I believe that there is a role for both modes of transport in their most efficient forms. But if it means that there will not be an increase in the number of large transport trucks on our roads, that in itself will lead to greater road safety. When one looks at the efficiency of using one or more locomotives to draw a number of rolling stock, one hopes that this will benefit the ecology of the country as there is less use of fuel and lower pollution.

There is one special area in which I have an interest and with which I should like to deal. I have seen some public reports of indications by Ministers that unless B(a)(iii) of the principles is agreed to, money will not be forthcoming. I refer to the operation of labour arrangements incorporated in an enterprise award. I think the notion there is very good, it is constructive, it is capable of succeeding and it deserves to succeed. I have seen many jobs lost on the railways. Rail has become more efficient.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen, who now occupies the chair, will know as a citizen of Queensland that the electrification and upgrading of the permanent way has given quite good profits to the Queensland Railways from the coal area. That can be expanded in terms of the National Rail Corporation if it is properly organised. The unions saw jobs disappear week by week. Although it did not make them happy because their members lost jobs, they recognised that that was progress and they have lived with it. In the same way they will look at this proposition in terms of the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill and what is required of them.

When the agreement is finally made, it should be detailed and clearly understood by all the parties. When it speaks of reflecting best practice and productivity standards through efficient work and manning practices, we are talking also about management. We do not want people who are doing the hands-on work at different levels in rail being efficient and doing their best having to cope with incompetent and stupid managements who do not know how to work with people, but who see people only as numbers in terms of the job to be done or as extensions of machines.

I make it clear that the responsibility there is not only with the work force at the lower levels of classification, but also with top and middle management. As efficiency develops some middle management will disappear because there will be no need for those people. A great deal of responsibility will fall on people throughout the whole of the industry as to how best to do things and how to make the industry work most efficiently in order to benefit the whole community. However, in benefiting the community, people connected with the railways have the right to expect the community to consider their work as useful, to receive proper and reasonable remuneration and to be given decent working conditions.

In the process of developing this enterprise agreement I believe that a great deal of attention needs to be paid to the fact that there will be private operators coming into the area. The agreement should contain provisions dealing with problems that may arise because of the arrival of private interests. I am not saying that the rail enterprise agreement will dictate the terms under which they should operate, but if there are problems because of some contradiction in the ways in which they approach work practices or management practices, I believe those matters should be dealt with in a proper, reasonable and measured way without any further disputation. Rail is one of the most efficient forms of transport in medium and long distances. I commend the Bill and offer my support in ensuring that it succeeds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate on the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill, which is a most important measure. It attempts to overcome one of the crucial areas of inefficiency, which perhaps in a perfect world could be addressed by amending our Constitution. As we have perhaps given away the possibility of making any substantive changes to the Australian Constitution in terms of our State-Federal relationships, I believe that the Government—not just in this area but generally—is proceeding down a far more sensible and pragmatic route in seeking to achieve these efficiencies, particularly in the area of transport, by cooperative arrangements between the Federal Government and the States, backed by administrative cooperation.

PARA.TAB: A substantive number of issues were raised during the debate and for purposes of the public record I will respond to them. I acknowledge the support which the Opposition and the Australian Democrats are giving to this Bill. I indicate that the Government will be supporting the amendments to be moved in Committee by the Democrats and the Opposition.

Some senators referred to two matters that were raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The first concerned clause 2 of the Bill. I understand senators were concerned because there is no time limit for proclamation of the Bill. It is clearly in the interests of all the shareholders for the NRC to commence operations as soon as possible. I take it from the tone of the debate today that that is also the desire of members of this chamber. I draw attention to the assurance given by the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee that the legislation will be proclaimed as soon as practicable. No time limit could be included as the agreement has to be approved by five parliaments. This has been done by New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland, and only the Commonwealth and Western Australia have yet to do so.
The second matter concerned the delegation of legislative power. This is not an issue as the Bill does not delegate any legislative power to the NRC.

A number of senators referred to the need to get the industrial arrangements right, and certainly I concur with that view. The Commonwealth and States in establishing the NRC agreed that to be successful the corporation would need the right mix of commercial management, capital investment and a greenfields industrial enterprise award. This award is currently being negotiated by the NRC and the rail unions and will incorporate best practice industrial arrangements which reflect the most efficient work and manning practices determined by the technical capacity of the equipment and commercial considerations.

The Government's commitment to getting these arrangements right was reiterated in the One Nation statement made last week by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The Government will be seeking firm commitments from the rail unions to a greenfields enterprise award and from States to accelerate rail reform in their rail systems.

The question was also asked as to what are the `best practice' industrial arrangements which the NRC is required to attain. These are precisely defined in clause B of the recitals to the agreement and are as a minimum those identified by the National Rail Freight Initiative Task Force in attachment 1 to its report of 21 March 1991.

Some concern was expressed that the NRC's enterprise agreement might be of only one year's duration and that it would be incompatible with private enterprise operations in the NRC system. In developing its enterprise agreement the NRC will seek to negotiate an agreement for the longest period it can. As it is intended to be a document embodying both flexibility and best practice, it is not envisaged that there will be any difficulties in private enterprise operating the various parts of the system such as the terminals.

The NRC will take on the interstate functions and associated assets of the existing rail systems. The remaining functions will remain with the existing rail systems. It will be up to each government to consider what it will do with these residual railways. I cannot speak for the Victorian Government, but the Commonwealth Government will be considering this matter in relation to Australian National in the near future.

It was suggested during the debate that the capital base for the NRC is inadequate. This is incorrect. Perhaps the cause of the confusion is that voting shares are set in the first five years. In this period voting shares are set at the levels agreed by the shareholders and set out in the schedule to the agreement. Cash and assets contributed are reflected by the issue of `convertible shares'. At the end of the establishment period these are converted to ordinary voting shares.

In so far as capital is concerned, in addition to the $415m that the shareholders will provide, the NRC will be able to borrow commercially to fund its capital requirements. Further, it will receive a boost from the $454m main line rail upgrading package announced by the Prime Minister on 26 February. In addition, the shareholders' agreement—clause 6(2)(a)—allows for the shareholders to make additional equity payments should these be required. As this will be done via the corporate plan process, any dispute among the shareholders would be settled by the special mechanism set up to resolve disputes over the corporate plan.

Some honourable senators referred to concerns that the referral of power by States for the NRC to engage in intrastate trade should be revokable. I agree with those honourable senators that it would place the Commonwealth in an awkward position if, after referring a power, States were to turn around and revoke it. However, that is the nature of the Constitution.

Honourable senators opposite referred to the mechanism for resolving disputes, particularly in relation to the transfer of assets for the NRC. The point they were making was not completely clear. The mechanism is clearly set out in part 7 of the shareholders' agreement. All of the parties have agreed to this process. I am advised that the process is to try to resolve any disputes by way of conciliation and, if this does not succeed, by arbitration. The intention is to avoid any lengthy, costly, legalistic or bureaucratic processes.

There seems to be some confusion about the approval of the corporate plan. The mechanism for approval of the plan is set out in article 118. It requires 75 per cent of the votes for the plan to be approved. However, during the establishment period, if for some reason one of the shareholders seeks to frustrate the approval process, a deadlock breaking mechanism will be invoked. This mechanism provides that, if the plan is not approved within 30 days, it can be approved if all of the shareholders bar one agree, irrespective of the number of shares each shareholder has. Given the need for shareholders to earn a return on their investment in the NRC, it is unlikely that any two members would seek to frustrate a commercially driven corporate plan. I add—this point has been made in debates in here before—that if it did get to this parlous position it would indicate that the entire process has been fundamentally frustrated anyway. We all hope that that will not happen.

Concern was expressed that the funds allocated in the Prime Minister's One Nation statement favoured road more than rail. The fact is that the Commonwealth's policy is not to favour one mode over another but to encourage each mode to undertake the tasks to which each is best suited. The emphasis on rail is therefore on the long distance carriage of bulk freight, with assistance being provided to the NRC to carry out this task.

A comment was also made that rail should not have to pay fuel excise. This was recommended by the Industry Commission in its 1991 report on the rail industry, which also acknowledged that this would have ramifications outside the rail sphere. The Government has this recommendation under consideration.

The comment was made that the NRC should not be responsible for the cost of funding redundancies caused by the establishment of the NRC. The Government agrees and this principle is in fact enshrined in the principles set out in the agreement, which is found in clause B of the recitals. It was agreed by the Commonwealth and the States at the July 1991 Special Premiers Conference.

Senator Powell raised the possibility that the NRC may be privatised. The fact of the matter is that no private sector operator would be interested in being involved with a loss maker, as interstate rail freight is at present. If at some time in the future private enterprise is interested in investing in the NRC, rail will have been turned into a commercial success and this Parliament could take some credit for that achievement.

Senator Powell also raised the issue of the Melbourne road link from the ports to the Dynon terminal. I advise the honourable senator that this will be an internal road connecting the ports area, crossing Footscray Road to the rail freight terminal. It will reduce, rather than increase, traffic congestion in Melbourne.

Concerns were expressed that the 49 per cent cap on any individual shareholding was not conducive to a commercial approach. Such a condition was necessary to achieve agreement to set up the NRC and was agreed to as part of a mechanism that ultimately allowed a single shareholder to acquire more than 50 per cent of the voting stock with the concurrence of the other partners. Such arrangements are a common feature of companies with a small number of shareholders and are entirely consistent with the intention that the NRC will operate as a fully commercial body.

The claim was made that the Commonwealth should fund upgrading of the track sufficient to allow fast freight operations, to allow a nine-hour transit time terminal to terminal between Sydney and Melbourne. Such transit times would, it is claimed, allow rail to compete in the time sensitive express overnight freight market which is currently captured by road. The concept of the FFT would require further investment of more than $1 billion to put it in place. Before an investment of such magnitude could be contemplated, a full and comprehensive financial evaluation would be needed, including real market opportunities available to rail with transit times of nine hours.

After all, road can offer a customer to customer turnaround time of as low as 12 hours in this corridor. The NRC will be undertaking a full study of its network needs and of the potential markets in which rail could effectively compete. It should not be forgotten that as part of the One Nation statement this Government has taken a significant first step in improving rail's performance and attractiveness to customers. The Government will be providing $454m over the next two years to complement the NRC's $1.7 billion investment program.

By 1995 there will be a complete standard gauge main line network between Brisbane and Perth. Further, rail will be able to achieve a reliable 12-hour transit time between terminals in Sydney and Melbourne and a 16-hour transit time between terminals in Sydney and Brisbane. The most important benefit of all of this rail investment is that, together with an NRC-greenfields work and management practices approach, it will lead to a significant improvement in reliability and quality of service offered by rail. This is an essential first step in improving rail's performance.

I have addressed those matters of detail that were raised during the debate. I also tried to follow as best I could, via our technological marvels in the building, the last contributions made to the debate this afternoon. I heard the contribution made to the debate by Senator Tambling, the National Party senator for the Northern Territory, in respect of the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link and the support which the Department of Defence has consistently given to this project and—I might add—which Defence Ministers in this Government have given to this project over the years. Senator Tambling criticised the lack of commitment in the One Nation statement of the Federal Government in supporting the construction or providing for the construction—which I think Territorians would be more interested in—of the Darwin to Alice Springs rail link.

Such an approach needs to be given some degree of clarification. One of the difficulties at the moment is that we do not actually have a proposal that could be sensibly supported by anybody. I know that it would not be supported by the coalition. The interesting thing about Senator Tambling's contribution to the debate this afternoon is that it is the sort of contribution we should expect to come from someone who is arguing from a position of some strength instead of from someone who, as Senator Tambling is, is arguing from a position of total weakness.

To indicate just how weak his case is, I have in front of me a copy of a draft policy for the Northern Territory written by Senator Tambling, which no doubt he proposes to release at some time in the future. In ploughing through this document, I was interested to try to find some ironclad commitment by the Federal coalition to construct the Darwin to Alice Springs railway. I think that was a reasonable assumption on my part, considering that he devoted the majority of his speech this afternoon to attacking us for not providing such a firm commitment, as he put it.

I was not surprised that I did not find it. His leader was in the Northern Territory only a few weeks ago. The Northern Territory journalists chased Dr Hewson on this issue—up trees, down rabbit burrows, around corners—and tried to extract from him a commitment that a coalition government would construct the Darwin to Alice Springs rail line. Of course, they failed. How could they do anything other than fail, considering that the coalition has promised to tax us all 15 per cent on the things we buy, through a consumption tax—15 per cent on electricity accounts, 15 per cent on telephone bills, 15 per cent on motel beds, restaurant meals and everything else? It would only be able to maintain what is, by world standards, a horrendously high level of consumption tax by extracting multi billions of dollars out of public spending to pay for it.

That is hardly a proposition that any coalition member could put with a straight face. To say, as Opposition senators do, that they will slash multi billions of dollars in restricted public expenditure—and that is the only way to maintain that horrendously high level of 15 per cent—when, at the same time, they know perfectly well that the only way to achieve that is by screwing down public expenditure to zero.

It is a nonsense. They may well argue for the rationale of such an approach in New South Wales or South Australia or, indeed, the southern end of Western Australia. I notice that a Labor colleague of mine, Bob Carr, at a recent Press Club luncheon here in Canberra, was advocating a per capita disbursement of Federal funding—in other words, to put the Federation clock back 100 years and take us back to being six fundamentally self-governing States, and to hell with any national vision.

The reason why I make that point is that the adoption of this kind of policy is not something that is confined to one side of the chamber. But of course, there is one part of Australia which I unabashedly and unashamedly say would be devastated by such an approach—an approach, of course, advocated by the Opposition—and that is the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the fuel levy. Tell them that in the Northern Territory.

—It would be an absolute drop in the bucket in terms of the saving that that would result in for the Northern Territory. In his sheltered life, Senator Parer may not have lived in the parts of Australia I have lived in. I have spent most of my life in isolated communities. One has only to go a short way outside of Darwin to see the horrendous costs which freight already imposes on goods in isolated communities of the Northern Territory, and to shudder. It would not be affected even slightly by the Opposition's proposal, in its total ignorance, to remove fuel excise. People will be quite literally unable to live on their current per capita income if the price of goods is pushed to the limits to which the Opposition proposes to push them.

PARA.TAB: What do we find when we turn to this wonderful document of public policy, written by Senator Tambling for the Northern Territory, in terms of the firm commitment that we need to the Darwin to Alice Springs rail link—or, if you live in Alice Springs, the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link? We read this in Senator Tambling's document:

SPEECH.PARA: Our review and negotiation of tax rules in respect to large, long term projects will see the completion of such projects as the long awaited railway from Alice Springs to Darwin.

That is it. What a piece of transparent, political nonsense that is. Of course, everybody in the Northern Territory will know that, if Senator Tambling has the hide to produce this document before he redrafts it at some point in the future. Those kinds of promises have been made for years. I can remember a spectacular one being made by a former Premier of Queensland some years ago when he committed himself, just prior to an election, to the construction of a Mount Isa to Darwin rail link. Stop laughing, Flo—he did. That was Premier Joh Bjelke-Petersen.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Senator Bjelke-Petersen' to you.

—Well, I am dreadfully sorry for putting my arm around the Queen, Senator, by being a bit friendly in here; but I dare to do so. It does not seem to have upset Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen to the extent that it has upset Senator Knowles; but that is hardly surprising. I humbly apologise. It was `Senator Bjelke-Petersen' who laughed at that allusion.

PARA.TAB: Of course, rail links announced prior to elections are treated by the electorate with the same disdain with which the announcement of international airports and dams are treated. They are given no credence at all. In fact, I cannot understand why politicians, in the context of election campaigns, even bother to utter them. We are used to this kind of waffly, non-precise statement, but the lie was given to this one just a few weeks ago when the Leader of the Opposition, Dr `Scorched Earth' Hewson, was in the Northern Territory and he flatly refused to be pinned down by anybody who spoke to him about giving anything even approaching a commitment to the construction of this rail link.

Of course, one fundamental thing that does have to be done is that, in light of the criticism that has been made of the most recent report into the rail link, that is, the Morrison Knudsen report by the Northern Territory Government itself, and the very detailed public criticism that has been made by the Minister for Transport and Works, Fred Finch, of the deficiencies in these documents, then the one fundamental thing that we need urgently is a clarified proposal, endorsed by the Northern Territory Government, of the two competing proposals—that is, the Railnorth proposal and the Morrison Knudsen proposal that are currently being bruited. We need to have some clarified position that the Northern Territory Government—of course, having checked this out through its Treasury officials—is prepared to put its name to and endorse as being a proposal worthy of support before anyone, whether Labor, Liberal or National Party, could come even close to giving any kind of a commitment of support. It would be impossible to responsibly give that sort of commitment sight unseen. Regrettably, that is the position we are currently in. We do not have a clarified proposal that would indicate the commercial viability of this particular overdue link in Australia's national rail transport chain.
I thank the Opposition and the Democrats for their support of this legislation and commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating in the Senate the Financial Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, which is a mechanical Bill. It deals with financial matters and thus it is relevant to the so-called One Nation statement that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) delivered last week. Naturally, one could not miss an opportunity to make comment on that because the debate regarding the One Nation statement is likely never to resurface in this chamber again, as is the case with the Budget debate and all other debates associated with it.

PARA.TAB: It is particularly ironic to have before us some highly specific changes to the Currency Act and the Financial Corporations Act when this Labor Government has put forward a program of sheer and utter economic disaster. I do not make this statement lightly and, of course, others have agreed with that statement that it is disastrous. It is not, however, a case of one nation as the Prime Minister would try to have us believe; it has merely been put together, pasted together, as a response to the coalition's Fightback package. Probably the person who summed it up most succinctly and accurately was a commentator who has not been known in the past for any great leanings towards us in the coalition, and that is Max Walsh, who simply described the One Nation statement as `reckless'. It is a cynical political document designed to buy votes at the Wills by-election and, of course, at the next general election without thought to the long term damage done to the Australian economy.

I find it rather staggering that the Prime Minister can actually come into the Parliament and put down the One Nation statement and believe that all is well, that all of the years of damage and havoc that he has wreaked upon this country can suddenly disappear with one statement. The people of Australia are not fools; they cannot be treated as such. The One Nation statement is the program of a Prime Minister who claimed to control all the levers of the economy and, if he has done that, he and we and the people of Australia all know the direction in which he has pushed the economy. Of course, he is the Prime Minister who gave us the recession that we had to have, who knows the writing is on the wall for his Government, and therefore has decided to put a distinct vote grabbing exercise together in one document.

It will be left to John Hewson to clean up the mess—a bigger mess than we are in today. The people of Australia know exactly what mess the Prime Minister has got us into. He is the one who has claimed to be the best Treasurer in the world; he is the one who has claimed that he has given us the recession we had to have; he is the one who has constantly claimed that he is in control; and he is the one who keeps on pushing the point that Australia can suddenly turn around and manufacture all the jobs that, as a result of his engineering, we have lost.

With equal cynicism, the Prime Minister has sought to deflect attention from the glaring weaknesses of his statement by an attack on a friendly nation calculated to stir up division in our community. It is not only the British in our community who are upset at his statement; there are many others—born and bred Australians—who are upset at the way in which the Prime Minister has attacked Britain.

It used to always be the situation that Prime Ministers and members of parliament generally were meant to be diplomatic, not meant to go around and poke out the eyes of other nations, yet this Prime Minister seems to care not. How disrespectful can a Prime Minister be to go cuddling up to the Queen at an official reception and then a matter of days later to start poking the eyes out of the British. It is absolutely and utterly disgraceful for a person who is meant to represent all Australians. I found it somewhat disturbing to listen to some of the reports from overseas which categorised us all in the same way in which the Prime Minister, quite rightly, had been categorised—`uncouth, uneducated, ill-mannered'. I do not believe that all Australians are in those categories.

What we are being offered in the absurd statement put down last week is $18 billion worth of unfunded spending and tax cuts based on wishful economic growth. Gone are the days of two years ago when a certain Treasurer told us that we as a nation could not have whatever infrastructure we wanted if we remained savings poor. Nothing has changed. We are savings poor today, and yet suddenly the whole theory on which he based his statements but a few short years ago has been turned on its head. It seems all right now to have all the items of infrastructure while we are still savings poor.

Just what would this Government have said about Fightback if the $13 billion worth of tax cuts that the Liberal and National parties will deliver had not been carefully costed, along with an honest and definite program of $10 billion worth of spending cuts? For years, every time any Liberal leader has stood up and advocated certain policies, the cry in unison from the Government has been, `Where will the money come from?', `Where is the evidence?', `Where are the spending cuts?', `But how are you going to cost your proposals?'. We had this glossy little performance last week with not one word, let alone one line, of where the money is coming from—it is totally and utterly unfunded. Of course, Labor is back to treating the electorate like fools, offering all the goodies in the world without providing the means to afford them.

If Labor succeeds in putting its package into effect there will be a very terrible price for Australia in terms of a foreign debt increase of over $100 billion over four years, taking us to $225 billion—well over $12,000 per head. But does Prime Minister Keating care? No, not in the slightest, because all of this is going to be done on the chit—on the never-never plan. It is a horrible thing to contemplate, but the Prime Minister intends to buy his way into another term of government.

While the 1.4 million jobs that the Hawke-Keating Government claims to have created have cost $73,000 each in international debt, so the 800,000 new jobs that we are being promised will cost $109,000 each in fresh debt. But does that worry the Government? No, because once again we are just going to buy our way out of trouble. Where does the money come from? Will we just have to keep on borrowing and taxing people more and more? We will certainly be into the banana republic scenario with a vengeance.

Inflation will blow out to 6 per cent as imports are sucked rapidly into Australia. Is it not amazing that, according to the Murphy model, GDP growth will be much lower than was suggested by Mr Keating last week, averaging 3.3 per cent a year instead of 4.3 per cent a year; inflation will blow out to 6 per cent, not 3 per cent; the current account deficit will increase to over $27 billion, not $20 billion; and net foreign debt will rise by almost $100 billion? Yet here is the Government saying that all is well. Here is the Prime Minister saying that nothing is going to be affected. I ask again: where is the money coming from? We make these predictions by using exactly the same economic model—the Murphy model—that the Prime Minister tried to use to discredit Fightback. Where is his consistency? It is simply non-existent.

The statement also fails Australia in terms of what it will not do. There is no labour market reform, only a revival of a discredited accord whereby the ACTU says, in effect, `We will go quiet on wage rises for a while so long as the system that works so well for us stays in place'. Yet we have Martin Ferguson from the ACTU saying that he wants real wage increases. Is that not great! He wants real wage increases. He has not a care in the world about how many more people that puts out of work. And the Prime Minister will not knock it on the head; he will not say, `No, there can be no wage increases'. He simply says, `We will think about it. We have not made a decision'. Yet, while the de facto members of Cabinet—Martin Ferguson and Bill Kelty—go running around this country saying, `We want more wage increases for the workers', they just do not have any understanding of the economics of staying in business and being able to afford the staff and all the infrastructure that goes with it.

If this Government were serious, why did it not abolish payroll tax—a tax on employment—in last week's statement? Why did it not abolish that stupid training guarantee levy that is so easy to manipulate? It did not do either of those things. All these taxes on employment have not been touched.

So long as the accord stays in place, there is not much sense in building new railway lines if the same unions with the same effective powers—unions which caused a $20 billion loss in the last 10 years—are running them. Where is the action to deal with the trans-Tasman union arrangement that prohibits competition and costs $110m a year? And what will be done to tackle waterfront security of tenure? Absolutely nothing. There is no place in One Nation for hard decisions. The Prime Minister has not made any hard decisions—they are all the soft options; they are all the easy things that might be able to be done.

But nothing is to be done to give Australia a health system that would deliver quality care, affordable to the individual and the wider taxpaying community, and slash the hospital waiting lists that now very conservatively stand at more than 60,000 people. The health system has simply remained untouched in this statement. Yet, at the same time, the Government is trying to restrict Medicare payouts to radiologists. It has already done over the pharmacists; it has already done over the pathologists; and now it is about to do over the radiologists.

The health system is absolutely shot to smithereens. Yet this Government will not look at the tough decisions of making the system work, encouraging people back into private health insurance and making sure that the facilities and services are available for people when they need them. Oh, no, the Government prefers to look at a situation where the doctors who are prescribing various treatments need to be curtailed. It looks at the person who is issuing the prescriptions. It then tackles the pharmacists. It blames the pharmacists for over-prescribing drugs. But this is not the case. Where is there one comment in this One Nation document about the failing health system? There is no answer to the realism that is presented by the Liberal and National parties that encourages self-provision through rebates for private health insurance—not one word.

And, of course, nothing will be done to remove those taxes that the Liberal and National parties will abolish, such as sales tax, petroleum excise and payroll tax. These taxes will just continue to cascade through the system and add on to every product every step of the way—with sales tax penalising exports by $600m a year. Yet, a little earlier on in the Senate tonight we heard Senator Collins go for broke talking about the 15 per cent increase that is going to be put on everything. Of course, that is the great Labor lie.

I was a bit disturbed. I thought Minister Kim Beazley would have been a bit more responsible in the way in which he is tackling this, but a report put out by him in January of this year contained nine notable untruths about Fightback!. Not one, not two, but nine. He said that the only major exceptions to the goods and services tax are some education costs and financial services. That is an absolute lie. If he wanted to have a look at it and if he wanted to report to his constituents accurately, he would say that it is not only some education, it is all education, it is all financial services, it is health, it is charities and it is a whole range of things that are exempt from GST or zero rating. But, no, he tries to scare people.

Mr Beazley tells people that pensioners will get an extra 8 per cent to cover additional food and medical costs. That is not true. Pensioners will get an extra 8 per cent for an expected rise of 4.4 per cent, but he is implying that there will be additional medical costs. What he does not say is not only that medical costs will be zero rated—a la no GST—but also that there will be no extra medical cost because pensioners will still be entitled to bulkbilling. But, no. Will the Government tell the truth? No way, because it does not suit its cause.

Mr Beazley does not say that many of the food items that are currently on the supermarket shelves are taxed with the hidden consumption tax of this Government. Such things include toothpaste, toilet paper, shampoos, washing powders and nappy wipes. All of those things are taxed at 20 per cent. The Government still does not say that the Fightback package will abolish all of those sales taxes, replace them with a 15 per cent tax and then, additionally, abolish the seven other taxes.

Mr Beazley went on to say that the expansion of private hospital insurance will do nothing to reduce pressure on the hospital system. How absurd that is in itself. If we are going to get greater utilisation of private hospitals by getting more people into private hospitals, surely that is going to provide greater utilisation when the private hospitals are, in many cases, currently under-utilised. There are very few private hospitals around Australia that have 100 per cent occupancy. Many are at 40 to 50 per cent occupancy; many are on the verge of closing and will never open again. Yet Mr Beazley tells the great Labor lie that the system will do nothing to reduce pressure on the hospital system. Of course it will.

Mr Beazley also claims that the 15 per cent goods and services tax will be on top of the price paid for the actual goods or services. He does not indicate that we are abolishing his hidden consumption tax: the 15 per cent, the 20 per cent, the 30 per cent wholesale sales tax. He does not say a word about that. He does not say a word about the 19c a litre fuel excise to the private motorist and the 26c a litre fuel excise to the business motorist. He does not say anything about that or the other taxes that are going to be abolished.

Mr Beazley also said that businesses will be under no compulsion to pass the savings on. He totally ignores the strengthened Prices Surveillance Authority under Fightback! and ignores the basic commercial drive for market share needing the price to be competitive. If one person is going to pass it on and the next person is not, I know who is going to stay in business longer.

He also claims that lower income earners will receive smaller tax cuts. How on earth can he say that when people who are earning an income of $20,000 a year will get a 28 per cent reduction and someone on $90,000 a year will get a 15 per cent reduction? What he also fails to say is that there will be a 100 per cent reduction to 350,000 taxpayers who are affected by the raising of the tax threshold from $5,400 to $7,000. So there will be an extra 350,000 people under the Fightback package who will pay no tax at all.

What has Mr Keating done about those very same people in One Nation? Nothing. As I said before, payroll tax will continue to restrict job creation and generate increased input costs for all businesses. The petroleum excise alone will continue to levy $3.6 billion on business, adding to the costs of exports to the consumer. Will the Government abolish the petroleum excise? No, it will not. It will still collect $3.6 billion on that factor alone. It is so easy to point out the differences between a program of reform where honest and visible indirect tax will replace those shonky hidden imposts and, of course, a grab bag of promises. It is only the Liberal and National parties that will cut input costs by refunding the goods and services tax on business inputs.

Another of the great Labor myths that is going around is that the goods and services tax will be charged at every stage of the manufacturing chain and that, therefore, the cost of the product right at the end will be more. At the moment, that is exactly what happens. Under the hidden consumption taxes of this Labor Government, sales tax is charged at virtually every stage. If a manufacturer wants to buy some equipment, he pays sales tax. If he wants to buy a truck, he pays sales tax. If he wants to put tyres on the truck, he pays sales tax. If he buys spare parts, he pays sales tax. On the list goes. If he wants to buy a light globe for his factory, he pays sales tax. He pays sales tax all the way along the line. He cannot reclaim one cent of it.Under the Fightback package all that sales tax will go and any goods and services tax that is paid on those business inputs will be totally refunded. What a different situation to that which is present today. Yet members of the Government continue to run around this country saying that the GST is going to be put on at every stage.

All we will get by way of indirect tax reform by this Government in the One Nation statement is a 15 per cent sales tax rate on motor vehicles—a concession, I might add, that does not extend to trucks. Therefore, all the trucks that carry all the produce, all the beef, all the sheep, all the cattle and pigs, all the Weeties and all the milk to the supermarkets will still pay 20 per cent sales tax. Under us, they will pay no tax, no sales tax and no goods and services tax because it will be fully refunded. Here is the Government saying, `We are a government of reform'; on the one hand there is reform, but on the other hand there is plain window dressing.

The contrast could not be greater in the area of family allowances where a one-off Keating Easter egg will descend just before the Wills by-election. Is that not amazing? The Prime Minister says rather cynically that this has nothing to do with Wills because the Cabinet decided on this a fortnight before Mr Hawke resigned. Is he trying to tell this whole nation that he and the Cabinet were the only ones who did not realise that Mr Hawke was going to quit? It is absolutely absurd. Mr Keating says, `Oh, no, we did not do this about Wills'. Oh, no. He can keep a straight face if he tries. Contrast this with the coalition's carefully targeted reform of family allowances that will be doubled for those families that most need it—those with incomes below $30,000 a year.

It is, indeed, the battlers in the community that get little attention from this Labor Government. I could not believe that even this Prime Minister had the gall to put forward supposed income tax reform that deliberately excluded well over three million low income earners from any relief whatsoever. This is the Government which maintains that it looks after the battlers. While we are advocating that well over 90 per cent of people will pay no more tax than 30 per cent, and that there will be an extra 350,000 people who will pay no tax at all, what is this Government doing? Absolutely nothing.

We are talking about 1.84 million women who earn less than $20,700 a year, often from part time jobs that have become essential to keep their families afloat. Labor seems to think that they are enjoying some form of income from wealthy husbands. We are also concerned about 450,000 retirees who earn less than that amount and who worry about the effect of taxation on their fixed incomes. We remember 820,000 young people earning less than $20,700, including students who are showing the initiative to finance studies through work.

I am particularly concerned that farmers who may be starting to earn income some years after the average broadacre farm loss of $27,500 in 1992-93 will be hit with current rates of tax. This Prime Minister and his Government do not know or care that a great many operators of farms and other small businesses are earning incomes well below $20,700 and deserve and need tax relief. The Government does not one thing about it.

I am proud of the fact that, under Fightback!, we are raising the tax threshold from $5,700 to $7,000 so that those additional 320,000 battlers will pay no tax at all. A taxpayer on $20,000 in 1994 will get a 30 per cent tax cut and a taxpayer on $10,000 will get a 47 per cent tax cut. What would they get under Labor? Nothing; not a thing.

As a Liberal, I believe in tax cuts for battlers for two reasons: firstly, it is a measure of social justice that Labor talks about but never practises to increase the disposable incomes of less affluent Australians by reducing or removing tax; and, secondly, it is essential that people in struggling small businesses and lower paid part time jobs be given incentive to work. If we do not reward these Australians for getting out and finding jobs, we cannot complain about a growing and insidious dole culture.

It is a national tragedy that under the Hawke and Keating governments we have reached a situation where 920,000 Australians are officially unemployed. The actual figure is much higher, but 920,000 is the number who are officially unemployed. Further, 760,000 people are on the dole, 260,000 families have their chief breadwinner unemployed, 248,000 Australians have been unemployed for more than 12 months and 220,000 children live in families where nobody has a job. It is this last statistic that is the most worrying.

This Government is doing nothing to give young Australians the incentive as well as the opportunity to work. There are 220,000 children living in families where no-one has a job. Yet former Prime Minister Hawke had the bad taste to say, `By 1990, no child shall live in poverty'. What are these 220,000 children doing? Living in the lap of luxury on the foreshore of Sydney Harbour? Not likely. Living in the Ritz in Sydney? Not likely. But former Prime Minister Hawke can do all that while 220,000 children live in real poverty.

Again, I am only glad that in Fightback! we have foreshadowed the practical incentive for employers to take on the long term unemployed under a realistic wage. We have bitten the bullet to stop the supporting parent's benefit becoming a way of life rather than a necessary temporary support.

The joke may well get very tired, but it has to be repeated: One Nation is really about one job, and that is the Prime Minister's job. It is not about any other people's jobs; it is purely and simply about the Prime Minister's job. It gives no hope for a sound economic future and real structural reform and gives nothing to the Australians who most need help and incentive. I do not believe that Australians are in the mood for jokes at the moment. It is a cruel joke Mr Keating is playing on the Australian people. At least the Liberal and National parties will not let Australians down, even though we will now be given an even bigger mess to clean up, thanks to Mr Keating.

The claims will go on and on about all the things that Fightback! will allegedly do in a negative sense. If the Government had half the courage it claims it has, it would have put all the Fightback proposals into its statement last week and we would have given it bipartisan support to turn this country around. It is a shame that we will have to wait until 1993-94 to start turning this country around, with such a weak, pathetic, unfunded statement as that which the Prime Minister made last week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The comments I shall make relate specifically to the Financial Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. Three matters are covered by it: firstly, the simplification of the procedures for the issuance of new coins; secondly, the delegation of certain statistical powers under the Financial Corporations Act by the Treasurer to Reserve Bank officials; and, thirdly, the repeal of the Special Employment-related Programs Act 1982.

PARA.TAB: The first thing the Bill proposes is to delegate the power of administering the statistical provisions of the Financial Corporations Act from the Treasurer to officials of the Reserve Back, although the Treasurer will retain a reserve power in this area. We do not oppose this measure.

The second matter is the proposed amendments to the Currency Act 1965. This Act was previously amended in 1987 to facilitate the production of the same coin denomination in different metallic compositions. It is interesting what we get to talk about in the Senate—for example, the metallic compositions of coins. Again, this is not controversial, although those 1987 amendments are ambiguous in certain areas, and this Bill seeks to clarify those ambiguities.

The more substantive matter relating to the production of coins is the proposal to alter the administrative procedures which are currently undertaken to approve new coins or to determine variations to designs or other characteristics of existing denominations. At the moment, all such procedures have to be done by way of regulation. It is claimed that the infrequency of Executive Council meetings and the amount of administrative work needed is causing problems with the marketing schedules of the coins. This Bill therefore proposes to transfer these powers to the Treasurer, although all decisions will be by way of a disallowable instrument which will be reviewed by this Senate.

The need for this administrative change is the rapid growth in numismatic or collectors coins. In this area, the Mint recently won a contract to supply $9m worth of gold and silver coins to the International Olympic Committee's centennial coin program. We should congratulate it on that achievement.

It is always interesting to find unexpected little complexities hidden away in seemingly innocuous legislation. Senator Watson smiles; I admit that he is something of a master at it. I would ask Senator McMullan, if he were here, to clarify for the public record advice that has been given to a member of my staff from the Treasury that this legislative change means that any decision to remove the head of the sovereign from an Australian coin does not need to be agreed to by the Governor-General, who represents the Queen in Australia.

Given the current focus of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on Australia's republican future, one could ask whether this was a colourful extension of the debate. Given also the reciprocal fervour of the Opposition, I would have to say that I am a little surprised that members of the Opposition did not spot this possibility in a close examination of the Bill. It is left to the usual Democrat attention to detail to unearth this gem of a possibility.

It is interesting to consider that, if we had followed our forward plan of last week, this Bill would have been debated at the time the Queen was visiting Australia. That would have been a real bottler. I am waiting for Senator McMullan's clarification of that proposal when we get to the committee stage.

The Royal Australian Mint is one of the oldest institutions of the Commonwealth Government. It is not a separate entity but a business unit within Treasury. I pay tribute to some of the achievements of the Mint, as the opportunity rarely arises in this chamber for a debate in this area. The Acting Controller, Chris Mills, in the 1990-91 annual report to Parliament, described the Mint as `a light metals manufacturer with wholesale and retail outlets'. That is rather a quaint description, I think.

In April 1991 the Mint became the first and only mint in the world to gain accreditation to international quality standard ISO9002. This is an international standard which emphasises quality in production and excellence in quality control systems in the production process. I think we should congratulate the work force of the Royal Australian Mint on this unique achievement. It is another example of how public sector enterprises can be efficient and competitive if they are properly managed. Indeed, the Mint is about the only government enterprise that is not earmarked for privatisation in the Opposition's Fightback package. We hope it is safe. Certainly it should be, given that economic rationalism appears to be on the nose at the moment.

As well as the high level of quality control, the Mint now has one of the world's most advanced coin production methods. The Mint joined with the CSIRO to develop the optical surface profiler. This device can measure all the dimensions of a coin mould in about 15 minutes instead of the many hours using traditional equipment. This leads to higher quality products at a more competitive price and should lead to an increase in export orders in the future.

A major issue of the moment, apart from the other one I mentioned, is the demise of the copper coin. The then Treasurer announced in the 1990 Budget that no new 1c or 2c coins would be minted or issued by the Mint from that time. From 1 February this year the Reserve Bank ceased issuing copper coins and the banks are now returning them to be melted down. The coins remain legal tender and the cent remains the smallest unit of account. Prices remain unchanged, although totals are now being rounded up or down to the nearest 5c.

I think it is appropriate to take a few moments to reminisce on the prominent place copper coins have had in the financial history of Australia. Governor Hunter received the first copper coins in New South Wales in 1800, replacing the previous currency of rum, and they have been in constant use since that time. Since decimalisation, a staggering 5.5 billion copper coins have been produced, weighing 20,500 tonnes and with a face value of $79m. After the issued coins have been repurchased, it is estimated that the cessation of the production of the coins will yield about $6m a year in recurrent savings to the Mint. In addition, there has been a one-off saving of $20m resulting from the disposal of surplus coin stocks of other denominations which arose because of the moneybox effect of large numbers of 5c and 10c pieces which have been returned to circulation along with the smaller coins.

The purchasing power of 5c and 10c coins is now much less than that of the 1c and 2c coins when they were first introduced in 1966, so I suppose we can agree that it is reasonable to phase them out. One undesirable outcome of the withdrawal of the small coins is the possible effect this will have on all the charity collection boxes that are placed in various outlets around the country. I think there are enough pressures on the resources of these organisations because of the recession without the further problem of falling donations in this way.

The final point I make on the subject of coins is the question of the under-representation of women on our coins. Apart from the Queen, there has been only one woman, Princess Diana, on Australian decimal coins, and she appeared along with Prince Charles. This is to be remedied in part this year by the release of a special $1 coin featuring a female javelin thrower, followed by a series of coins entitled `The Royal Ladies' commemorating 40 years of the reign of Queen Elizabeth II. It is good to see the imbalance beginning to be redressed, but I think it would be more appropriate if the considerable achievements of Australian women were also to be recognised on our currency.

In its nineteenth report of 1991, dated 27 November 1991, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills considered the Financial Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, now before the Senate, and concluded that the administrative changes proposed in respect of the Currency Act amounted to Henry VIII clauses and, as such, should be drawn to the attention of honourable senators. Senator McMullan gave a very comprehensive answer to the matters addressed in the Committee report. Rather than cover that ground again, I seek leave to have the report of the Committee incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: FINANCIAL LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991
This Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives on 10 October 1991 by the Minister Assisting the Treasurer.
The Bill proposes to:

amend the Currency Act 1965, to provide the Treasurer with the authority to approve new coins, determine variations to design and/or other characteristics (by disallowable instrument), without reference to Executive Council; and
amend the Financial Corporations Act 1974, to permit the Treasurer to:

PARA.TAB: -delegate to the Governor/Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank responsibility for varying and publishing the list of non-bank financial institutions which fall under the Act; and
-publish the varied list as appropriate rather than being restricted to the Gazette; and

SPEECH.PARA: repeal the Special Employment-related Programs Act 1982.

The Committee dealt with the Bill in Alert Digest No. 17 of 1991, in which it made various comments. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer responded to those comments in a letter received 13 November 1991. A copy of that letter is attached to this report. Relevant parts of the response are also discussed below.
`Henry VIII' clauses
Clause 4—Proposed new sections 13 and 13A of the Currency Act 1965

In Alert Digest No. 17, the Committee noted that clause 4 of the Bill proposes to repeal section 13 of the Currency Act 1965 and replace it with sections 13 and 13A. Proposed new subsection 13(1) provides:

PARA.TAB: Standard composition of coins
13.(1) Subject to paragraph (2)(a), the standard composition of the coins of the denominations specified in the Schedule is as specified in the Schedule.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new subsection 13(2) provides:

PARA.TAB: (2) The Treasurer may, by signed instrument, determine that this Act is to have effect, on and after a day specified in the determination, as if:

TAB.TAB: (a)a reference in the Schedule, opposite to the denomination of a coin, to the standard composition of coins of that denomination were a reference to such other standard composition as is specified in the determination; or

(b)there were included in the Schedule a reference to a denomination of money specified in the determination and there were specified in the Schedule opposite to that denomination, as the standard composition of coins of that denomination, the standard composition that is specified in the determination.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee noted that the existing section 13 provides:

PARA.TAB: (1) The standard composition of the coins of the denominations specified in the Schedule is, subject to subsection (2), as specified in the Schedule and the standard weight of those coins is as prescribed.

(2) The regulations may, from time to time, provide that this Act shall have effect, on and after a date specified in the regulations, as if a reference in the Schedule, opposite to the denomination of a coin, to the standard composition of coins of that denomination were a reference to such other standard composition as is specified in the regulations and, where any such regulations are made, the standard composition specified in the regulations shall, on and after the date specified in the regulations and while the regulations remain in force, be deemed to be specified in the Schedule opposite to that denomination in lieu of the standard composition actually specified in the Schedule.
