(3) Regulations made for the purposes of this section may specify more than one standard composition or weight in relation to coins of a particular denomination.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee noted that this means that, currently, the composition of the coins is set out in the Act but can be varied by regulation, as can the standard weight.

The Committee noted that under the proposed new section 13, the composition of the coins would be, in effect, as set out in the Schedule or as the Treasurer otherwise determines. The Committee indicated that, as such, this was a `Henry VIII' clause, as it would allow the requirements regarding composition set out in the primary legislation to be amended by subordinate legislation. The Committee also noted that such amendments could be made by Ministerial determination rather than by regulation, as is the case under the existing provision.

In making this comment, the Committee acknowledged that such Ministerial determinations would, pursuant to proposed new subclause 13(6), be disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. However, the Committee also noted that, in general, such instruments are not as well drafted as regulations, nor as readily accessible.
Similarly, the Committee noted that proposed new section 13A provides:

PARA.TAB: Standard weight, design and dimension of coins

13A. (1) The Treasurer may, by signed instrument, determine, on and after a day specified in the determination, the standard weight, the allowable variation from that standard weight, the design and the dimensions of a coin whose denomination is specified, or taken to be specified, in the Schedule.
(2) The Treasurer may specify in a determination more than one standard weight, design or set of dimensions, in relation to a coin of a particular denomination.

(3) Where the Treasurer specifies in a determination more than one standard weight in respect of a coin of a particular denomination, the Treasurer must specify in that determination an allowable variation in respect of each such standard weight.
(4) A determination is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee suggested that, if enacted, this provision would allow matters such as the standard weight, the allowable variations from the standard weight, the design and the dimensions of the various coins specified in the Schedule to be amended by Ministerial determination. Under the existing section 13, standard weight could only be varied by regulation. The Committee suggested that, in either event, this is a `Henry VIII' clause, as it would facilitate the amendment of the primary legislation by subordinate legislation.

The Committee noted that it has maintained an in principle objection to the use of `Henry VIII' clauses. The Committee also noted that, in the present case, the `Henry VIII' process was being made even less acceptable by changing the method of amendment from regulations to Ministerial determinations. The Committee noted that, on the whole, regulations are well-drafted and, by virtue of their being published in the Statutory Rules series, relatively easy to find. The Committee suggested that the drafting of Ministerial determinations is often not up to this same standard and there is no such obligation to publish them, which can make them difficult to find.
The Committee indicated that it would appreciate the Treasurer's views as to why it is necessary to change the method of amendment from regulations to Ministerial determinations.
The Committee drew attention to these provisions, as they may be considered an inappropriate delegation of legislative power, in breach of principle 1(a)(iv) of the Committee's terms of reference.
The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer has responded as follows:

It may assist the Committee if I briefly outline the reasons for the earlier amendments to the Act, as well as those currently under consideration. Under the original provisions of the Act, each time a new coin denomination was introduced or the standard composition (metallic composition) of an existing coin was varied the Act had to be amended, although other coin characteristics eg design, weight and size could be varied by regulation.

In 1981, in the context of amending the Act to provide for the issue of a new coin denomination, the opportunity was taken to amend the Act to enable all such matters to be determined in future by regulation. This was seen as providing for greater flexibility in the type of coin that could be issued without the need for additional legislation. The previous process was considered impractical from the viewpoint of enabling the Royal Australian Mint to develop its numismatic coin program, as approvals for new coins or variations to the composition of existing coins were required on a regular basis.

The reason for now changing the approval arrangements from regulations to disallowable instruments reflects the changed situation with regard to coinage. There has been a substantial increase in recent years in approvals sought for new coins and variations to coin characteristics with the expansion of the RAM's numismatic program and the production of precious metal coins by the Gold Corporation, a statutory authority of the Western Australian Government.

The practicalities of successfully issuing collector coins into what is an extremely competitive market demands, inter alia, elaborate marketing programmes, maintenance of tight production schedules and adherence to advertised release dates. In light of this and the increased administrative burden generated by the expansion of the number of collector coins being issued, it was recognised that there was a need to simplify the administrative process. Considerable administrative effort is required to make regulations.
The Parliamentary Secretary goes on to say:

The Committee's other concern relates to the view that instruments are not, in general, as well drafted nor as accessible as regulations. While I appreciate the Committee's concern in this regard, I would point out that the Attorney-General's Department will be closely involved in the drafting of the instruments. Moreover, as the basic format of the present regulations and the proposed instruments are expected to be very similar, I see no reason why the quality of the instruments should suffer in comparison.

As far as accessibility of instruments is concerned, while instruments under the Currency Act will not form part of the Statutory Rules series, the proposed amendments to the Act have been drafted so that all other avenues for scrutiny and accessibility currently applying to regulations made under the Act will also apply to instruments under the Act. The Treasurer's determinations will be tabled in both Houses of Parliament and be subject to disallowance, and will be published in the Gazette, as occurs at present.

Furthermore, I would emphasise that it is important to the issuing bodies, the Royal Australian Mint and the Gold Corporation, that such documentation is both well drafted and accessible as they are required to demonstrate to overseas authorities, as well as their wholesalers and dealers, that their coins have legal tender status. It is of particular importance in the case of overseas authorities, as without that status being established, they would be unable to obtain the necessary sales taxation exemption to enable them to compete with other numismatic products internationally. I would emphasise that exports are an important component of sales of collector coins.
The Committee thanks the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer for this detailed response.

TALK.START.PARA: —The final area covered by this Bill is the repeal of the Special Employment-Related Programs Act, which implemented the job creation schemes that were funded by the public sector wages pause decided upon by the Fraser Administration during the recession in the early 1980s. It is in this area of job creation that the One Nation economic statement has been so inadequate and even callous.

PARA.TAB: Back in 1982 the Labor Party opposed the wage pause and the contingent job creation scheme. However, they did introduce an administratively superior job creation scheme, in my opinion, the community employment scheme, to address the problem of massive increases in unemployment which arise during recessions. The social costs of unemployment, especially long term unemployment, are huge and are largely avoidable if compassionate and responsible policies are implemented by the Government.

At the moment we are witnessing a ratchet effect of an increase in the level of long term unemployed after each recession over the past 20 years. This tendency, coupled with increasing substitution of capital for labour and the export of jobs through the elimination of tariffs, will lead to the creation of a permanent underclass which will have disastrous social consequences. We know this. We do very little about it. There is a myth that any kinds of community-based employment schemes are not real jobs. I question that. Why are they not considered real jobs? We have this cultural malaise in Australia of short-termism. Every member of Parliament has an employment span which is determined by the next election. Does that mean the short term of our tenure means that we do not have real jobs? Of course not. When there are no employment possibilities in the private sector, why is it wrong to create public sector jobs to carry out worthwhile local projects that improve the quality of life of local residents until private sector employment opportunities improve again.

The Australian Local Government Association went to see Treasurer Dawkins to put to the Government a proposal to spend $1 billion to fund almost 600 urgent local projects, which would have created up to 100,000 jobs immediately—real jobs, meaningful jobs at the local community level. The Evatt Foundation proposed that about 200,000 jobs could be created by the Commonwealth spending about $2 billion via local government. We could have a real Better Cities program. But the One Nation package continued the Government's compassionless course and did not contain one initiative for a community-based employment scheme. This is a fact which I think will follow this Government to the next election, copper coins or not, republican agenda or not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In debating the Financial Legislation Amendment Bill, I wish to make some comments on the recent statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) called One Nation. I ask the Senate: how on earth can any reputable man stand in this Parliament, make a statement in which he calls upon the Australian people to work together to become one nation and then, the very next day, divide the country as it has not been divided for many years? According to David Jenkins in the Sydney Morning Herald:

SPEECH.PARA: In his seemingly off-hand remarks about the monarchy and his tilt at Britain's alleged betrayal of Australia in 1942, Paul Keating . . . has exhumed some of the class and religious antagonisms that divided Australia more than 50 years ago—and shown a sometimes shaky grasp of history.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating is from an Irish-Catholic, working-class background. . . . one can hear in Mr Keating's words an echo of the Protestant-Catholic divisions that persisted well into the 1950s, at which time, mercifully, successive overlays of migration began to make those differences seem less significant.

There is an us-and-them aspect to the Prime Minister's recent remarks that belies his rhetoric about building "one nation". At the same time, there's something contrived about his newly minted nationalism.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Jenkins said a little later:
Suddenly he is out kicking heads wherever he can find them, at least for show. First the Americans, then the Japanese, now the British. The Indonesians must be getting twitchy.
I ask, which country comes next? Mr Jenkins says:

It is not accurate to say that Britain failed to defend Malaya and Singapore. . . . . . . Nor is it accurate to say the British would not let us have our troops back when we needed them. As the historian Dr David Horner has shown, the 6th and 7th AIF Divisions were sent from the Middle East to the Far East at Churchill's suggestion. It was when Churchill wanted to divert them to Burma that Prime Minister John Curtin insisted they come home.
We all know, at least those of us who can remember, what strains Britain was under at that time defending the free world on her own.

PARA.TAB: Tony Wright of the Canberra Times on Saturday also made this comment, which I thought was most appropriate:

SPEECH.PARA: How strange. In the same week as the Australian Government grovelled to hypersensitive Malaysia by dissociating itself from the film Turtle Beach, the Prime Minister, Paul Keating, has attacked a member of the opposition as heirs to the old fogeys who grovelled to Britain. . .

PARA.TAB: The old grovel to Britain is nothing but a historical memory to the majority of Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: We all remember very clearly Senator Evans standing there and grovelling, as he did in this Parliament a short time ago to Malaysia.

PARA.TAB: I believe that Mr Keating's statement proved beyond any shadow of doubt that he was running scared of Dr Hewson's reply to his statement. He believed that if he did not say something controversial to take the headlines, the damage that Dr Hewson would wrought on his statement would be quite exceptional.

Let me now refer to the financial statement that Mr Keating gave last Tuesday—that unfunded statement of $2.4 billion. It was, as I have said, completely unfunded. It was done on a surmise that something would happen, that there would be growth during the coming years, and that that would set everything right. No hard decisions were made, and there were no government cuts—not a dollar of government spending was cut. We all ask, as Senator Knowles did a short time ago, `Where on earth is the money coming from?'. The Government has asked that on many occasions, but on this occasion Mr Keating blatantly said, `No, I haven't costed it, I haven't funded it, I don't know, but I presume it will come'. All this was said at a time when one million people are unemployed.

There will be without any doubt a greater gap than there is already between the haves and the have-nots. What worries me particularly is that at the moment we have a million unemployed. Those with jobs are doing all right, even though the cuts in their living standards are quite considerable. But the very large number of unemployed—and they are becoming longer term unemployed—are a considerable concern. There is no mention in the fantastic financial statement of Coronation Hill, of the development of extra runways at Sydney Airport, or of anything else. There is no mention at all of those matters.

I wish to deal with one particular area and to compare it with what we as an Opposition have already proposed in our Fightback package. I ask again what the Government has done for, to quote Senator Button, the terrible misery and distress. We all know that the Prime Minister has taken full credit for that. He has said that he engineered the recession; he organised it and believed that it was necessary; it was the recession that we had to have. He made all those statements, admitting eventually that it was organised by himself. But the Labor Party here was so insensitive that it then decided to elect that Treasurer, a man who was lacking in all credibility, to become Prime Minister. With over one million unemployed, well over a million under-employed, the Labor Party decided to elect as its Prime Minister this man who caused it all.

What has been done for those unemployed people? The Department of Social Security in Hobart rang my office at lunchtime on Tuesday and said that it would like to brief my staff. My staff was asked whether they could keep 10 a.m. on Friday free because the Department thought that would be a good time to brief them on the Prime Minister's statement. On Wednesday morning the Department rang back to say, `We will cancel that because there is nothing in the statement that we can brief you on'. That perhaps points out more clearly than anything I could say how the poor are being treated in this financial statement.

What have the poor in the community got? On 2 April there will be a one-off payment to all on family allowance. Of course, not only the poor get family allowance, but those on over $40,000 a year receive the allowance. There will be a one-off payment of $125 per child—a one-off excuse, a one-off `I am sorry' from Mr Keating—for causing this recession.

Mr Howe was asked, `What is the price of a pair of good quality running shoes?'. He said, `I am not up on those costs at the moment'. When the interviewer said, `Let me tell you, Mr Howe, it is $125, so that will be gone on one pair of running shoes', Mr Howe was not even concerned. The families of the poor will get $125 as a one-off `I am sorry' from Mr Keating.

On 2 April people will also get $3 per child for family allowance supplement. The people who get family allowance supplement, at least some of it, can earn up to $40,000 and can have assets of $359,250. So it is not the really poor who are getting some family allowance supplement.

The Government has decided that it will also give tax cuts, but the tax cuts do not come to the poor—not to the really poor. Senator Richardson was asked today in Question Time, `Why are there no tax cuts for people who are getting $350 a week and under?'. He said in his answer, `There is no need, we've already done that. We corrected their situation last year and the year before and ever since we've been in. So there is no need to give them any more—they're all right, they're in the boat, they're fixed'. Only those who are wealthier will get the tax cuts.

There are one million people unemployed. The former Prime Minister, as we know, said, `No child will be living in poverty by 1990'. In case the Labor members do not go out and have a look in the community, let me tell them that there are many children still living in poverty. This economic statement does nothing for them at all. I will give the Senate some examples. Someone on $350 a week, presently paying $49.20 in tax, will not get a tax cut under this Government. Someone on $400 a week, presently paying $60 in tax, will get a 10c tax cut in 1994. That is appalling, that is criminal, particularly when someone on $900 gets a $21.50 tax cut but someone on $350 does not get a cent. Most people could not believe it and, therefore, it took a couple of days before the welfare organisations started to show their concern.

I compare what the Government is doing for the community and what the Opposition, as a government, would do with its Fightback package. I will go into a little more detail with regard to tax. As I have already said, the Government is not giving any tax cuts to the poor. I refer again to the $350 a week family which does not get any tax cuts. Under us they would get $14.30 a week, which is a 29 per cent tax cut. On a lower income—say, $140 a week—they would get a 87.5 per cent tax cut. They presently pay $7.20; we would give just about all of it back—$6.30, an 87.5 per cent tax cut.

The Government starts at $400 with a 10c tax cut; that is, a 0.17 per cent tax cut for someone on $400. As the income scale goes up, the tax cut percentage increases. With $500 one would get a 4.27 per cent tax cut; with $700 one would get a 7.29 per cent tax cut; with $800 one would get a 8.40 per cent tax cut. It continues to go up, but under us at $140 it is 87.5 per cent. We go down as income increases; our percentage decreases as one earns more income. The Government's percentage increases as one has more income. It is something that I find extraordinarily difficult to understand and it is certainly against any philosophy on this side of the chamber. The poor should be helped, and the poor are those least able to pay tax, and therefore should be asked to pay tax less than those on higher incomes.

I compare the packages for someone on, say, $20,000. Under the Government's system there will be no tax cut for the family on $20,000; under us the tax cut will be considerable. They will save $814. They will be paying 16.2 per cent tax instead of 20 per cent tax under this Government. Petrol excise will be abolished; the GST will be put on. Under the Government there will be no saving for this family—not a cent. They will still be paying 69c to 70c a litre for petrol. But under us there will be an 18c to 19c a litre decrease. They will not be paying as much for their petrol.

I refer to the dependent spouses rebate. Under the Government there will be no increase in the dependent spouses rebate; under us there will be a $300 increase. I refer to the family allowance supplement. Under the Government there will be a $3 increase, but under us there will be a $3.29 increase for those with children under 13. For families with children over 13, the Government will still only give them a $3 increase, but under us it will be $4.79. There is no alteration to family allowance under the Government's package. Family allowance will be exactly the same. Of course, let us not forget that they get their one-off payment of $125. But under us the family allowance will be doubled.

I refer to superannuation. There is no alteration at all for superannuants under the Government; under us there are considerable incentives. I do not have time tonight to go into all of the incentives, but there will be incentives for people on an income of $20,000 to take out superannuation. Should people take a lump sum there will be no tax on that lump sum. Under-35s buying a first home will be able to use 75 per cent of any accumulated superannuation that they may have; under the Government they are not entitled to do that. Under us they will be given $2,000 to compensate them for building that home and 50 per cent of that building will be free of GST. Again there is nothing from the Government.

I refer to savings. Under us people will be entitled to earn up to $2,000 interest without any tax. That is not so under the Government. If someone saves a few bob they will be taxed to the hilt on it. There will be nothing for them under that. As I have already said, we will be abolishing not only the petrol tax but seven taxes in all: payroll tax, petrol tax, wholesale sales tax, lump sum superannuation tax, the coal levy, the training guarantee levy and customs duty. There will be a 4.4 per cent increase in living standards.

People have been saying—indeed, many of the Labor people in Tasmania have been saying it—`You'll have 15 per cent put on your bread and butter.' The Australian Supermarket Institute, when asked to put what it believed would be the increase on the supermarket shopping basket, said, `Our initial calculations show that the impact of the Opposition's GST of 15 per cent on the supermarket shopping basket will be an increase in the region of 3 to 5 per cent. This may be a surprisingly low figure but very few of our customers have realised the impact on food prices of the current wholesale sales tax, which will be abandoned by the Opposition when in government'.

We know that the Government has, if you like, a GST on all food in the supermarkets. It has a payroll tax, and a petrol excise. It has a number of taxes that all impinge on the food in the supermarkets. Every bit of wrapping has a wholesale sales tax applied to it—the wrapping on butter, the lot. There is a wholesale sales tax applied to every item in the supermarket. As the Australian Supermarket Institute says, `People are unaware of the full extent of the impact on food prices of the current wholesale sales tax'. As it said, we will be abolishing that.

There have been some very naive statements coming from members of the Government to the effect that payroll tax does not affect small businesses—the corner store, and the supermarket. We know that is rubbish. They know that is rubbish.

Let me follow through a pound of butter. The cream is bought from the farmer, who does not pay payroll tax. It then goes to the manufacturers, who do pay payroll tax. Once that payroll tax comes off, the price of butter will be less.

There is a wholesale sales tax on a number of items. The petrol excise starts from the farm gate, all the way to the manufacturer. Because the excise and the 15 per cent will go on that truck taking the farmer's cream to the manufacturer, the cost of transport will be so much less that the price of butter will come down—not just from the reduction of payroll tax but from the transport taxes and wholesale sales taxes that presently apply to the trucks, to the spare parts, to the oil, to the petrol. The costs will naturally go down.

Government members are very dishonest when they say that a 15 per cent GST will apply to bread and butter and all other supermarket items, because they know that that is incorrect—unless they are not thinking at all.

In his statement, the Prime Minister pinched a number of items from our Fightback package. We do not mind him pinching them—they are good policies, and he has taken quite a few of them. We congratulate him on accepting them. The national power grid is a typical example. That was in our Fightback package. The Australia-New Zealand air market was in our package. The capital gains tax relief for business, again, was in our package. The one-stop development approvals, Dr Hewson has promised. Emergency relief for voluntary organisations—a good idea—was in our package. Training programs for the long term unemployed, again, was pinched from our package, as were assistance to non-Government schools, the foreign banks entry, accelerated depreciation for business, and more funding for TAFE. As I say, we happily let the Government take those. We would like it to acknowledge them and, as it takes them, at least say that it is accepting the correctness of the Opposition's approach.

But the entire Fightback package cannot be taken unless the goods and services tax is also taken. Every single area of our Fightback package is funded. Every single area says where the money is coming from. The fact that the Prime Minister has not indicated one area of funding but relies on the supposed increase in growth is irresponsible in the extreme and, indeed, will only result in higher interest rates. As the Government has realised already, long term interest rates have already gone up by half a per cent. There will be higher interest rates, higher inflation and, as a result, the inevitable higher taxes. Mr Keating will not be able to deliver those tax cuts, any more than the previous Prime Minister was able to deliver his promise that by 1990 no child would be living in poverty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call on Senator Short, I think I should mention to the chamber that standing order 194 says, among other things, that a senator shall not digress from the subject matter of the question under discussion. The question under discussion is whether the Financial Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 be read a second time. The speech that we have just heard did not relate to that question at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might have to seek your guidance, Mr Deputy President, in some of the remarks I will be making, because I have treated this legislation, the Financial Legislation Amendment Bill, which is an omnibus Bill dealing with financial legislation and which incorporates amendments to the Currency Act and the Financial Corporations Act and the repeal of the Special Employment (Related Programs) Act 1982, as offering a fairly wide field in which to make some comments on the general state of the economy and the nation, and what ought to be done about it. Perhaps I will need to seek your guidance.
—I am sure you will be able to do that.

—I thank you for your consideration, Mr Deputy President. The Financial Legislation Amendment Bill, as I have just said, is an omnibus Bill which makes several amendments, most of them non-contentious, relating to the approval procedures for issuing new coins. It does other things as well, as I have just said, but so far as the procedures relating to the issue of new coins are concerned, at present the approval of new coins, including variations to the design and the metallic composition and weight, necessitates regulations made by the Executive Council.

PARA.TAB: The Currency Act 1965 provides for the Governor-General to make regulations for the issue of coinage. Constitutionally, acts of the Governor-General are required to be made on the advice of Executive Council.

The Bill proposes amendments to streamline the procedures by authorising the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) to grant the necessary approvals for the production of new coins. One of the points that I think Senator Kernot mentioned, which we might take up in committee when Senator McMullan might be able to provide us with some answers, is set out in the explanatory memorandum which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed amendments to the Currency Act provide the Treasurer with the authority to approve new coins, or determine variations to design and/or other characteristics of existing denominations, by signed disallowable instrument, without reference to Executive Council. It is expected that these procedures will lead to considerable administrative savings.
It goes on to state:

Parliamentary scrutiny of new coins determined by disallowable instrument will, however, be retained as required under section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. The latter provides for the same scrutiny as now exists for regulations made by Executive Council.

I would be interested to hear from the Government some quantification of the expected administrative savings in all that, because it marks a considerable change to the discretion given to the Government in a change to the coinage and could have not inconsiderable significance in that respect. But as I say, I foreshadow raising that in committee, depending on Senator McMullan's summary at the end of the second reading debate.

PARA.TAB: There are two other amendments in the Bill which are unrelated to the issue of coinage. The first is to the Financial Corporations Act 1974, which permits the Treasurer to delegate to the Reserve Bank the responsibility for varying and publishing the list of non-bank financial institutions which fall under the Act. This affects the procedure but not the substance of the Act. The other amendment repeals the Special Employment-related Programs Act 1982. That Act was introduced to appropriate money saved by the previous government, the Fraser Government, as a result of the 1982 wage pause arrangements and to use it for employment generating purposes.

All the activities under that Act are obviously now complete and, indeed, have been since 30 June 1984 and all moneys paid out have been duly accounted for. As the Act serves no purpose, as the Government says, it makes sense to remove it from the statute books. These are commonsense measures and, naturally, the coalition does not oppose them. The first two amendments amount to a streamlining of administrative procedures, subject to the point I raised in relation to the currency, and the third removes an Act which is no longer required.

On the question of the roles and functions of the Reserve Bank, it is appropriate to point out to the Senate that, since the appointment of the new Prime Minister (Mr Keating), it is increasingly likely that Australia is returning to an era of political manipulation of the Reserve Bank. The Senate should not forget, nor should the people of Australia, that it was the Prime Minister who, when he was Treasurer, boasted that, `I have the Treasury in my pocket and the Reserve Bank is in my pocket'. It was the same Treasurer who also boasted, `The Treasurer, that is me, has responsibility for setting interest rates as is customary'. So there we have it. We now have a Prime Minister who, when Treasurer, openly declared his manipulation of monetary policy. Does anyone believe that he would not do so again for political reasons?

We saw further evidence of the Prime Minister interfering with the operations of the Reserve Bank for political reasons at a recent conference on monetary policy in Melbourne, where most contributors referred to the problems for the economy which were caused by monetary policy being influenced by short term political considerations.

The work by academics, retired senior public servants and others has pointed consistently to the pattern of monetary policy being eased just before each of the past three Federal elections, only to be tightened afterwards in an attempt to correct the damage done. So, no matter how hard the Governor of the Reserve Bank might protest, I do not think the easing and tightening of monetary policy being influenced, at least, by the political cycle, on the empirical evidence available, can be denied.

The experience of this Government's track record on monetary policy and the Reserve Bank's role in monetary policy and its relationship with the Government do not engender any optimism for the future. It certainly cannot be said that the Reserve Bank has placed the high priority on price stability that, under a Hewson led government, we would certainly give as a fundamental priority for the Reserve Bank.

Looking at recent history from 1985 to 1987, Australia's inflation rate soared to three times the OECD average. That was no imported inflation. It was old-fashioned pump priming to artificially boost growth to make the Government look good in advance of the elections that were occurring at that time. I remind the Senate that these were the days when the accord was at its height; the same accord which was supposed to avoid inflationary pressures. Of course, we now all know that that failed very dramatically.

So the question arises: what was the Reserve Bank doing? Why did it not use its powers to challenge Government policy? The answer can be found, in part, in the difficult relationship that the Reserve Bank has with government. That is occasioned by a variety of reasons, one of which is the Reserve Bank Act which stipulates the relationship between the Bank and the government. As I said earlier, the coalition in government will change the legislation to ensure that there is a much clearer separation between the Bank and the government.

There are other reasons as well. Looking at the composition of the board of the Reserve Bank, one sees some members for whom the objective of price stability would rate a long way behind protecting their positions of power and influence in other areas. I think my colleague Senator Kemp, who is following me in this debate, may say some things relevant to that.

Let us be quite clear about it: some members of the board of the Reserve Bank are there by the grace and favour of the past and present Prime Ministers. That is, always has been and always will be the Labor way—a special deal for your mates. Therefore, it is hardly surprising that questions are raised— increasingly nowadays, and have been for some time—about the setting of monetary policy and whether it has, indeed, been set in a way that is simply to take account of the needs of the economy, or whether there have been political motivations involved in some of the actions in relation to monetary policy as well.

That is a very important issue when we look at the situation facing Australia now. One of the top priorities that it is said both sides of politics share is a wish to place price stability and the maintenance of price stability as a top priority. It is certainly a top priority of the coalition—the next government.

Although it is said to be a priority of this Government, one must seriously question that that could be the case when one looks at the economic statement that was produced by the Prime Minister last week. Of all the criticisms one can make of that economic statement, and I believe that those criticisms are very considerable indeed, the No. 1 problem with last week's statement—apart from the fact that it has no direction for Australia, and no sense of vision at all for the future of this country—the single greatest policy weakness in it, was that in itself it has set the seeds for an inevitable upsurge in interest rates and inflation in this country.

If a political party in government was serious in saying that it had price stability high on its list of priorities, it could not conceivably have introduced the economic statement that this Government did last week. To have a situation where it is generally accepted that we need to increase the level of savings in this country—in that context, the public sector has a major role to play—and to find in the economic statement last week that the Government is deliberately budgeting for a Budget deficit, therefore drawing on the pool of the nation's savings, over the next four years of $20 billion is fiscal irresponsibility and recklessness almost beyond the memory of most people in Australia today. We have to go back to the Whitlam years, which were a major blip on the historic economic policy calendar—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not even good arithmetic, let alone good economics. It is a very small percentage of GDP.

—As we debated a similar situation last week, I have to draw Senator McMullan's attention again to the fact that those percentage figures he is parading around to show that the deficit will be a very small proportion of GDP are based on a growth rate of the economy and therefore of the revenue collections that no-one believes. Senator McMullan cannot get up and say it, I know, but even he could not possibly accept the growth projections and therefore the revenue projections on which his scenarios for the next four years are based.

PARA.TAB: On Senator McMullan's own figures, the situation is that over the next three years the Government will have to go to the market to raise almost $20 billion, presumably in Commonwealth bonds. That $20 billion is on top of the existing outstanding debt denominated in Commonwealth bonds of $34 billion. In other words, over the next three years this Government will increase its demands on the capital markets of this country by no less than 57 per cent above the existing levels. There is no-one who would be prepared to say that the consequences of that will be other than major pressure on the market, major pressure on interest rates, and major pressure on the economic recovery that, hopefully, the private sector would have been able to expect to see coming out of this recession over the period ahead.

What the Government has done with its economic statement last week is to abort the private sector recovery that one would expect out of the economic cycle and the worst recession we have had for 60 years—a recession, I again remind the Government, caused entirely by the policy mismanagement of this Government. The Government is going to strangle the private sector, prevent it from getting on with the job of creating improved living standards, creating jobs, and doing something for the one and a half million Australians that the policies of this Government have rendered unemployed or underemployed and the millions of Australians who have suffered a loss in real living standards as a result of those policies.

The Government had the unbelievable arrogance to come into this Parliament last week and say that it was going to introduce tax cuts to benefit low and middle income earners. Forty two per cent of all income taxpayers in Australia earn less than $20,500. Not one of those taxpayers will get 1c tax reduction as a result of the announcements in the economic statement last week. No Australians will get a cracker until 1994. That will be the first instalment; the second one comes in 1996. On neither of those two dates is there any reduction at all in the income tax rates applying to the low income section of this community—a section which, I say again, is more than 40 per cent of the total taxpaying population in Australia.

In addition, there was no provision in last week's announcement by the Government for paying back to taxpayers the insidious bracket creep, the tax creep, that has ripped $22 billion-plus out of taxpayers over the last five or six years simply because of the increased tax take as a result of inflation. In itself, therefore, it is an automatic reduction in real living standards. There is no lifting of the minimum tax threshold; it now stands at $5,400. There is no provision for that to be changed in the Government's economic statement. The coalition's Fightback proposals, on the other hand, lift that threshold from $5,400 to $7,000, which means that several hundred thousand more Australians will not pay any tax under us. Indeed, the other lower income taxpayers who earn between $7,000 and $20,700 will also experience significant reductions in their income tax payments.

For a so-called Labor Government to say seriously to the people of Australia, `We are concerned about your future, we want to try to help you find work, to have an economy that grows more, to increase your living standards, to find jobs, but we will not give you 1c in tax reductions' is unbelievable. The traditional base of the Labor Party must find words failing them to describe the attitude of a Labor government towards those people in our community who are in most need of the relief that tax reductions will give them.

The other fraud about last week's economic statement is that it will do anything meaningful to get the private sector going again. What has the statement done? It has done something by way of increased accelerated depreciation arrangements. These are good; we do not object to those. Indeed, the decision to have accelerated depreciation is contained in the coalition's Fightback proposals. But it is only a small part of what needs to be done to provide the incentive and the opportunity for business in this country to get taxes off its back so that it can lower costs and be more productive and competitive in an internationally competitive world.

Why did the Government not follow the coalition's proposals and abolish payroll tax? Payroll tax is a tax on jobs, a tax on employment. That is why the coalition will abolish payroll tax. It will take $5 1/2 billion off the back of businesses and put it into business's scope to create jobs.

Why, if the Government is really serious about getting down the cost of business, does it not do anything about the exorbitant amount that it is raising, and has raised progressively over almost the past decade, from fuel excise? When this Government first came into office the excise on fuel was 6c a litre; now it is about 25c or 26c a litre. The coalition is going to abolish fuel excise because it has become a milch cow which has nothing to do with energy conservation and nothing to do with providing better roads for Australia. All it is is a way of raising revenue by ripping off motorists and the community, and adding enormously to the costs of business, in order to finance the spending binges that have been the hallmark of this Government in its period in office. It is because this Government is unable to control itself when it comes to expenditure that it has had to fleece the business taxpayer and the private taxpayer blind to attempt to meet those bills.

The real problem, the major one, is that despite everything that this Government said in 1985—despite everything that the now Prime Minister said when he was the most articulate exponent of a goods and services tax in 1985—it is now not prepared to introduce a goods and services tax. Unless the Government is prepared to introduce a goods and services tax in conjunction with the abolition of the wholesale sales tax—

TALK.START.PARA: —And payroll tax.

—And payroll tax and fuel excise tax and several of those other taxes that add to the cost of doing business—the net result of which, I remind the Senate, is a one-off price increase of about 4.4 per cent, which will wash out of the system in 12 months. Unless it does this, it is saying to the Australian people, `We are not prepared to take the decisions to bring the Australian taxation system into line with the modern world. We are not prepared to give our exporters a break. We are going to keep slugging our producers and our exporters with these hidden taxes, particularly the wholesale sales tax which cascades right through the whole cost system in Australia'. A goods and services tax would not be paid at all on business inputs or on exports. It would give an enormous incentive to the business sector to lower costs and therefore to be more competitive, to create more jobs, and to be able to compete overseas and against imports in the domestic market.

PARA.TAB: Unless the Government is prepared to do that, then it really cannot claim to be getting towards first base in being fair dinkum about tackling the underlying fundamental problems that are the cause of our lack of productivity, our lack of competitiveness and, therefore, our lack of ability to compete in an internationally competitive world, and our lack of ability to create jobs for our existing work force, for our young people and for our not so young people.

I do not know how many members of the Government have visited parts of Melbourne such as the electorate of Wills and surrounding areas—the Labor heartland—in which my office and Senator Kemp's office are located. They should come and see the misery and the hardship that their policies have caused there. Come and see the 40 per cent plus of young people who cannot get a job. Come and see the 20 per cent of adult males who cannot get a job. Those opposite should come and tell them why they are not prepared to take the decisions that will enable business to be more competitive, to be able to create jobs, to get this country going again. Those opposite should tell them why they are not going to give them individual incentive, opportunity and hope for the future. Come down and tell them that. I will be very interested to hear the answers because there are not any responsible answers that those opposite can possibly give to those people who live in the wasteland of the Labor heartland that once was theirs.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I thank you for your indulgence. I have ranged a little wider than the strict content of the Bill. But it is fundamentally important that these things be aired and debated because the future of this country is at stake over the next 12 months. The economic debate that is taking place in this country today and that will take place until the next election will determine the future of this country for the rest of this decade. We will have to poise as we wait to see what sort of a country Australia is going to be, what sort of a people we will be, and what sort of job creating nation or otherwise we will have as we go into the twenty-first century. So the debate is essential. I think it is very important that senators on both sides of this chamber take every opportunity we can to debate these fundamental issues. Unless we do, we will be letting ourselves down; but much more importantly, we will be letting the people of Australia down.

This is not the first time that I have spoken on this matter and it is by no means the last. I repeat that the Opposition is not opposing the Bill. We support the Bill, which is essentially non-contentious. I hope that Senator McMullan will be able to address in his remarks the issue that I raised about changing the provisions in so far as the currency is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not only in Victoria's interest that the [Cain] Government be returned on 1 October. It is also in the national interest.

gave to the John Cain personality, and consistently, there might have been a greater expose by that newspaper of the decisions and policy of the Victorian Government.

SPEECH.PARA: There has recently emerged an encouraging downward trend in our current account deficit. This will diminish our external debt and GDP ratio before 1990.

Let us just reflect on that. In 1987, Mr Keating predicted that foreign debt would start to decline by 1990. Madam Acting Deputy President, you and I know that foreign debt has not declined but has risen quite dramatically. Two years later, after the March 1990 election, Mr Keating said:
That is my expectation that we will stabilise the debt at the end of this current term.

That will not happen either. So we have this Prime Minister's persistent role of ceaselessly making assurances to the Australian people about what will happen under his Government, what will happen to taxation, what will happen to inflation and what will happen to jobs. So I ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President, whether after eight years of this persistent misleading of the Australian people we should now put aside our experiences of this man and believe what he says in his One Nation statement. The answer to that must surely be an absolutely resounding no.

Honourable senators can probably remember that at Question Time today we asked Senator Button about the 800,000 jobs that Mr Keating has again promised, whether we should treat those promises with more importance and whether there was any likelihood that his promises about privatisation, consumption taxes, recession, taxes, inflation, foreign debt and so on would be kept. We asked Senator Button today in this chamber where those 800,000 jobs would be created.

Senator Button, as he is wont on these occasions when he is asked a question which requires a proper response rather than a general level of abuse, effectively said to us that he was not quite sure where they would be created but that they would generally occur throughout the economy. When pressed on the issue, he said that he believed that tourism was one area in which he thought numbers employed would continue to rise. He was then asked what the people in the north-west region of Melbourne where the electorate of Wills is situated could be told about the jobs which would be created. As honourable senators would know, Moonee Ponds, Coburg and Northcote are located in that region. The plain fact is that Senator Button was in effect urging us to take his promises and the promises of his Prime Minister on trust that somehow employment would be created for those people.

Massive problems have already emerged from the economic statement that Mr Keating brought down in the Parliament last week. He has now launched on a very substantial program to spend up big. You and I who are from Victoria, Madam Acting Deputy President, have had experiences since the early 1980s of governments that spend up big. There is no question that if spending up big was able to create sustainable jobs we in Victoria would be the most prosperous people in this country, because no-one has spent up bigger than John Cain and Joan Kirner. As you and I know, that did not create sustainable jobs; it created a little fillip in employment and most of those jobs occurred in the public sector and areas related to the public sector. We now find ourselves in this once great State of Victoria in a state of penury and near bankruptcy.

I am reminded, as the Senate may recall, that there was a battle for some six months over whether Mr Hawke should go. In the end, the Labor Party decided to opt for Mr Keating. I was sent a little poem by a constituent, a gentleman by the name of Mr Greg Shalless, who I think has been described as Australia's ultralight poet laureate. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no explaining this mob,
For years they were captained by Bob,
But when the recession
Became a depression
They gave its designer his job.

Through that little poem Mr Greg Shalless reflects the concern of most Australians that the man who caused the recession, the man who delivered one million people to the dole queues, was not punished for that; he was rewarded. Mr Hawke, the man who to his undying misfortune appointed this man Treasurer and let him run the engine room, got dumped in the end and the Labor Party appointed the man who had run the ship on to the rocks—an astonishing feature of that party.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I will draw one last statistic to the attention of Senator McMullan at the table. We now have one major constraint in expanding the economy which we did not have in 1982, which is the last time Mr Keating and Mr Dawkins spent up big—and boy did they spend up big in those years before they ran us into the currency crisis of the mid-1980s.

There is a very interesting table published in this week's Economist. That table looks at the current account deficits as a proportion of GDP. It lists 13 major countries in the industrial world and notes their balance of payments positions. It is very interesting to look down this table. I ask honourable senators which country they think is in the worst balance of payments position of the 13—this is after one of the most severe recessions this country has had this century, and certainly the most severe recession for 60 years.What country has the worst balance of payments record out of the 13 industrial countries? There are no prizes for this. The worst country is Australia.

The Economist shows that the balance of payments deficit was 3.7 per cent of gross domestic product in 1981 rising this year to 3.8 per cent, and this is the worst of these 13 industrial countries.
