—That is what I intend to address. In so doing, I wish briefly to make comment on the Martin inquiry into banking and deregulation, the conclusions and recommendations of which were published in a booklet entitled Pocketful of Change, which was distributed to members of the Parliament. I want to draw the attention of the Senate and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, hopefully, to a response to the conclusions and recommendations document issued by the Foreign Currency Borrowers Association in a booklet which, again, I think was distributed to all members and senators.

PARA.TAB: This matter has been raised in the Senate over a period. It has become more and more precise as time has gone on. It has brought to the attention of the Australian public the number of very honest and hard-working Australians who have lost everything as a result of the banking system and the foreign loans scandal, as some people call it, that occurred in this nation in the mid-1980s. What is so tragic about this is that the people who have really been hurt are those people who are the backbone of Australia. Many of them were farmers, small businessmen, people who had started with nothing and by a lot of hard work, a lot of enterprise, had built up quite considerable estates.

In the mid-1980s, at a time when this Government had allowed interest rates to blow out to what we then thought were exorbitant rates of about 15 per cent—and, of course, we know now that 15 per cent was pretty cheap compared with the rates eventually reached—these people, because they were struggling with interest rates of 15 per cent, succumbed to the lure of offers of foreign currency at 6 per cent. At the time this happened I was in practice as a lawyer in a small country town. I knew nothing about foreign exchange and foreign loans; I never pretended to and always knew where my abilities ceased. But it seemed to me, on looking at it, that it was just too good to be true. It just could not be that a person had to pay 15 per cent interest in Australia and then, suddenly, someone came along and offered that money at 6 per cent interest. There had to be a catch.

People consulted me about it and I sent them away to get better advice. I simply pointed out to them that it just did not seem that the world was like that—that the real rate in Australia was 15 per cent but that somehow they were going to get their loan at 6 per cent. A lot of people and small businessmen, who are much more clever than I at running a business, went to the people they trusted most—the banks they had dealt with for 50 years. For generations their families had dealt with banks, and banks in Australia at that time had an enviable reputation right around the world as being solid, conservative, honest and trustworthy and of doing everything in the best interests of their customers.

These people went to their banks and in some instances were given good advice, but in other instances they were caught up with what the Foreign Currency Borrowers Association alleges was a push by some banks to maximise their profits. In the Martin inquiry it was suggested that, with deregulation of banking and with foreign banks coming in, there was a necessity for the Australian banks to compete. There was a belief that the banks coming into Australia with deregulation would offer these foreign currency loans and that, if the local banks did not compete, they would lose these long and valued customers.

That was the reason put forward by the banks for getting into this. The Borrowers Association has suggested that they got into it because there were huge profits to be made, considerable tax advantages to be gained and, in some instances, individual people within the banking system trying to make something out of it for themselves—not necessarily in money but in promotion and kudos within the banking system. It is against that background that I wish briefly to raise this matter.

This booklet, which I think is very well done, put out by the Foreign Currency Borrowers Association, gives a definition of what foreign currency loans are all about. It quotes the State Bank of New South Wales as describing a foreign currency loan in this way:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a loan denominated in a currency other than in Australian dollars.
It then quotes what I think is a better description from the Commonwealth Bank, which indicates that a foreign loan is `a set of obligations'. It continues:

The particular obligation that is relevant is the obligation to repay the amount borrowed in the currency borrowed and to make all interest payments in the currency borrowed. The fact that both the principal and interest payments must be made in the currency borrowed attracts the exchange risk. The exchange risk is that every time a payment has to be made it has to be sourced from Australian dollar funds and the rate of exchange may not be the same at the times of payment as it was when the funds were originally borrowed. This can work in favour of the borrower or against the borrower.

That was what these loans were all about. I do not wish to come to a conclusion. I want to ask the Parliamentary Secretary to do something at the conclusion of my short speech. However, I do wish to raise a couple of matters that have been raised by the Borrowers Association arising out of the Martin inquiry.

PARA.TAB: Many court cases were taken by the banks against their customers. Some were settled, some were won by the customers, and some were lost. There were allegations of very unequal contests in court. From constituents who came to me and showed me documents—and, as a lawyer, they mean a little to me—I know personally of situations where the contest was unequal. I myself have had experiences in my practice where, if one has a large corporate client who is determined to go the whole hog, that client can force someone out of the business because he has not got the money to carry on.

Generally, the legal profession is a very honest one and one of very high standards. Most lawyers follow those very high standards and do their very best. But with some regret I must say that there are occasions when, on instructions from clients, and particularly in big commercial matters, big firms acting for big commercial clients will take every little point, every interlocutory action, to run the opponent out of the battle. That is cause for some distress, and I know it is a matter that is being addressed in the costs of justice inquiry. There were these unequal contests. There is this allegation of failure to discover documents. In fact, one prominent case has been sent back for rehearing on the basis that the bank would not discover documents which should have been the subject of discovery in the course of the trial.

A number of constituents who have come to see me are still battling it out with the banks. There are, of course, these last minute settlements that are offered by the banks when the funds of the borrowers are just about finished. In many cases that have already been settled, the borrowers have simply taken what they can get as the last straw because they are not in a position to keep going. They take a few bob just to save the house they live in, in many instances giving away the businesses for which they have worked all their lives.

Some friends of mine, who had very profitable hotel businesses in my own home town, fell victim to these foreign loans and just gave up. I have suggested to them that if they ever had the energy they might be able to take on the broker and the bank that gave them the money. But they have just given up. They have walked away from it. They have accepted bankruptcy after a lifetime of building up this business. I think that is very sad.

There are allegations from the Association that banks, at times with reckless indifference, gave money to clients who should not have been given it and did not fully advise their clients. I do not want to make any judgments at this time because this is a very complex matter, but these allegations are around. There are allegations that the banks knew the Australian dollar was falling in 1984, that they predicted it in a few years but still went ahead lending money to their long and valued clients without even raising the possibility with them that the Australian dollar might fall.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or not to hedge.

—Or not to hedge, as my colleague points out. Even customers of the banks who were successful, competent and learned businessmen in their own right were not fully aware of how the foreign loans worked in terms of exchange rates and certainly were not in a position to give the matter the day by day, or indeed minute by minute, attention that is needed if one enters into foreign loans and currency dealings.

PARA.TAB: There are allegations that when disaster struck and the Australian dollar fell against the Swiss franc quite dramatically, the banks did not do what one would expect them to do. It is alleged that they did not alert their customers, they did not give them help, or if they did it was very belated.
There are also allegations quoted by the Foreign Currency Borrowers Association involving a Swiss banker, Dr Henry Stalder, who said of Australian banks:

SPEECH.PARA: That senior bank officers who manipulated Australian business people and farmers into Swiss foreign bank loans between 1984 and 1986 are little more than criminals and should be in gaol.

He said that he would come to Australia to testify to that effect. Whether he is correct is a matter that one day might have to be pursued, but the fact that a Swiss banker would make that allegation is cause for concern.

PARA.TAB: The Martin inquiry talks at some length about a mediation process. I am pleased to say that some of the banks have adopted mediation. I do not want to mention names as I do not want to be a part of a system to denigrate any particular bank at this stage, but there is one bank, a local bank, which apparently has done the right thing by its customers. It has mediated, got rid of all its problems, and is only carrying on with those that are obviously quite fishy. There are a couple of other Australian banks which have not been quite as honest in their dealings, but of late it appears that they are coming more and more to the mediation process, particularly as recent disclosures come out. Every few months, and to a certain extent at the behest of the Foreign Currency Borrowers Association, more and more information is coming out. More and more evidence is being obtained as to what happened in those days in the mid-1980s with these foreign loan currency matters.

I am pleased to see that the banks generally are looking a bit more closely at mediation and trying to resolve some of these issues. I can only urge that the banks generally do that, and not only with the people they are fighting in the courts at the moment, but also with some of those who have already settled, either voluntarily or semi-voluntarily, and even with those who have been to court and who have had judgments against them or judgments that were not quite what they had hoped for.

There are allegations in these documents and in many court cases too—I do not give credence to them, but simply raise them—that banks were getting secret commissions; that is, that they were being paid more than once for the same job. There are allegations of banks point taking—taking additional interest, additional rewards over and above what they were entitled to. There is some evidence in this material that the banks were simply just picking a figure. If they had lost money on other foreign currency transactions on that day, they simply loaded it on to these people without any rhyme or reason, without any particular scale to follow. It was simply that if they had lost so much on other dealings that day, they had to retrieve it or jobs might have been on the line, so that they just plonked it on these small people—the little people, the farmers, small businessmen, the one or two million dollar asset people who have borne the brunt of this.

There are allegations, I understand—and I do not understand this matter as fully as some—that the banks were actually trading themselves with their customers' money. It is alleged that they were making profits out of trading with themselves on behalf of their customers and making money that way. There are also some fairly serious allegations of tax evasion having been undertaken by some banks. As I have said, I do not want to give credence to them, but the Martin inquiry has heard evidence of them and has made comments. The Foreign Currency Borrowers Association in its quite detailed and well presented submissions also refers to it.

I shall not keep the Senate for much longer. I wanted to raise the issue now. It is unfortunate that this is an inquiry of a House of Representatives committee. It means that unless we manufacture some courses to enable us to talk about the matter in the Senate, it will not come before us at this stage. I intend to look into the matter and pursue it further at a later date. I have been approached by a number of constituents. I am watching and am trying to assist where I can so that they can come to some conclusions with the banks.

I do not pretend to give legal advice or to be in any way expert on the matter because it is a matter of great complexity, but I intend to watch with interest what happens and hope that matters can be resolved. I hope that the banks will look seriously at mediation and get to just solutions in all those issues. If it appears that the banks are not responding, if the Martin inquiry feels that there are other matters that should be looked at or if the Foreign Currency Borrowers Association feels that there are still matters that need close scrutiny, it may be that the Senate should set up its own inquiry into various matters raised.

The Foreign Currency Borrowers Association report has called for a number of things. I shall not take up the Senate's time by reading them out, but I would refer honourable senators to the first and second pages in the covering letter which sent the document to us all. The Association indicates in that letter what it wants. It wants a royal commission. The Martin inquiry was not too much in favour of a royal commission. I am not sure that a royal commission is the way to go, but the matter does require further examination. Possibly a Senate committee might be the avenue for a close look at some of these serious allegations. I hope that this may not be necessary. I hope the matters can be resolved amicably so that the banks can get on with their business and to a certain extent resurrect the high regard that they used to have in the minds of the Australian public.

I ask Senator McMullan in his reply to indicate what is the Government's attitude to the conclusions of the Martin inquiry, particularly to the submissions made to all members of Parliament by the Foreign Currency Borrowers Association. I do not know whether Senator McMullan personally has had the opportunity of glancing through the submission or whether he has asked his officers to do so, but I would like some comment from him as to where he feels we should go from here and as to the Government's attitude. I imagine that the Government will be making a response to the Martin inquiry's recommendations, but I would appreciate it if at this stage he could give some indication on these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the Financial Legislation Amendment Bill, which is an omnibus Bill covering a large number of amendments, including amendments to the Currency Act. Madam Acting Deputy President, I notice that you have let the debate range far and wide. I hope you accord me the same treatment you accorded others.

PARA.TAB: Before I go any further, I should like to support what Senator Macdonald has said with respect to foreign currency borrowing. Honourable senators may remember that I have spoken before on this matter, which was brought to light by former Senator McLean from New South Wales. He made it quite a project while he was here. I fully support everything Senator Macdonald said tonight. I have gone into this pretty well with borrowers from Western Australia, Queensland and New South Wales. In fact, I will be seeing the Foreign Currency Borrowers Association in Queensland the week after next.

The bank which seemed to get all the blame from former Senator McLean was Westpac. Honourable senators will remember the Westpac letters. I have said before in the Senate and I will say again that when all of the washing is hung out, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia will make Westpac look like a kindergarten outfit. In addition to the book Comments and Further Submissions to the Parliamentary Banking Inquiry, another book is being sent to everyone called Which Banks are Still the Bastards? I recommend it to people. It makes very good reading and gives a different insight. I will be interested to hear what Senator McMullan has to say at the end of the debate with respect to Senator Macdonald's comments.

The debate this evening has ranged far and wide with respect to the One Nation package. I intend to address briefly a number of points. If Senator McMullan wants to take a point of order because I am wandering away from the subject, I will let him do so and you can rule on it, Madam Acting Deputy President.

The One Nation statement delivered last week was intended to turn this nation around. As I have said before, I thought we already had one nation, but in the last ten years this Government has made it many more than one nation: it has created about ten. One way or another, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is trying to bring it back. I can see that the Government's advisers are amused about this subject but I will continue on this line until I am stopped.

There is no joy whatsoever in this statement for the agricultural and mining industries. I have read the statement from front to back. It is simply a package designed to answer the Hewson Fightback package and it has done very little in that regard. In fact, it is not within a bull's roar of the Hewson package.

I believe that the main thrust of the package is to reverse a lot of the ill-advised decisions this Government has made over the past three years, and I will list some of them. Let us look at the measures the Government has included. The first is what I refer to as the Nissan effect—the wholesale sales tax on cars. The tax has been dropped by 5 per cent—from 20 per cent to 15 per cent—on cars under a wholesale price of about $30,000, or about $45,000 retail. That is an admirable way to go. After all, the Hewson package will eliminate sales tax altogether. In this case, the Prime Minister has just picked those cars which cost up to $45,000 retail on which to drop the tax from 20 per cent to 15 per cent. The luxury car tax still remains at 30 per cent on cars over that value. Honourable senators will remember the decision, which was reversed not long ago, with respect to the super-luxury tax of up to 50 per cent. The Government found that fewer cars were sold so it backed off on that tax quite some time ago.

The Government has reduced the tax on cars by 5 per cent. If it wants to encourage business and the selling of cars—and Senator Button omitted this today in Question Time—that 5 per cent reduction in wholesale sales tax on vehicles should apply to trucks, delivery vans, utilities and motor cycles, which are used in delivery service businesses and so on. Those vehicles continue to be taxed at 20 per cent. If the Government wanted to stimulate business and cut business costs, it should have included those vehicles in the 5 per cent reduction. It is patently stupid to have a vehicle—which one could say has a certain luxury about it because one could use public transport—which delivers goods, delivers messages, delivers come what may, still attracting tax at 20 per cent, or 5 per cent higher than for a sedan. It is one of the most ridiculous measures in the whole package.

I refer to the accelerated depreciation schedule that we have heard so much about. I am in favour of accelerated depreciation to stimulate business, but what has the Government done? How much has it accelerated? We have not had the legislation for the previous system, which was to start on 1 July 1991, but it will come and it will apply to plant bought after 12 March 1991. Taking that as the standard at the present moment, a machine with an effective life of from three years to less than five years can be written off at 2.5 years under the old system—the one that has not come in yet. Under the new system it is 2.5 years.

I turn now to a machine with an effective life of from five years to less than 6 2/3years. This applies to most machines with a motor in them—whether it be a tractor, a header, a bulldozer, a scraper or whatever. Under the old system, the previous rate, including the loading, was 36 per cent, with a write-off period of 4.2 years. Under the new system it will be written off in 3.75 years. How accelerated is that? It is patently stupid to say that it is accelerated. It is only six months. What further encouragement does that provide for someone who is thinking of buying bigger plant or extra plant? I cannot see any reason whatsoever.

The next category is machinery with an effective life of from 6 2/3 years to less than 10 years. The previous rate was 27 per cent, with an implied write-off period of 5.6 years; the new one is 5 years. So the Government has brought it down by six months. That is not worth having.

On the night Senator Button delivered this statement in the Senate he said that machinery being written off over 20 to 30 years had come down to a maximum of seven years. That is a good move, but it still will not make a great difference. If someone writes off machinery much beyond seven years, inflation will have an effect on it. If someone is writing off $100,000 over 20 years to 30 years as compared to seven years, inflation has eaten away the effect after seven or eight years. So the Government has not given the businessmen as much as it seemed at the time. I appreciate the little measure the Government has proposed, but it is nowhere near as accelerated as it makes out. I turn now to business company tax deferral.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Panizza was right: a lot of other people had a lot of licence in this debate, so I have not wanted to stop him from speaking. However, I point out that it is about 10 o'clock. His speech is outrageously out of order, but everyone else's has been, so I suppose he has a right to be as out of order as them. I hope he will wind up fairly soon so we can actually get on with the program. This is half a point of order to say that in five minutes or so we will have to start raising the point of order seriously. Senator Short at least made passing reference to the legislation in his address before going on to other matters. I raise this matter as a preliminary point of order.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Senator Panizza, perhaps you would just try to keep your comments related to the Bill that we are considering this evening and, perhaps, as Senator McMullan suggested, shortly bring your comments to a conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for the poetic licence you have given everyone tonight. I will continue on this Bill until I am told to do otherwise, because I know that you make good and just rulings at all times. However, the point is that it is a money Bill and I believe that the measures that have been spoken of by my colleagues and by me tonight are relevant to what is going on in Australia today.

PARA.TAB: Deferred company tax on a company with a profit of under $400,000, deferred for nine weeks, was a measure that was only brought in about 18 months ago. Here the Government is now reversing it. Eighteen months ago company tax could be paid in four instalments. The Government became greedy, and there it goes—one big deal, nine weeks' deferral.
The Minister is getting impatient, so I will move on—although he will not hurry me altogether.

There is to be extra spending on roads of $600m. Let me refer to my chart on road spending under this Government. When we compare the spending in the last budget of the Fraser Government of $1.282 billion, we find that this Government, in real terms, has cut road spending by 18 per cent. A small calculation shows that this Government has underspent on roads by $2 billion in eight years. Now it is giving the roads $600m to make up for it.

What are we getting out of this package? We get $454m for rail, with far more than that being neglected. Then we come to the rural sector. This Government has said that it will give woolgrowers back their own money. This was debated in this place last year, and Senator Cook, who led for the Government, would not listen for one moment to the argument that a 12 1/2 per cent wool tax was too much. Now the Government is making a big deal with the farmers by giving them back their wool tax, giving them back their own money. How much has disappeared under administration? They are some of the things the Government has done in a complete reversal.
I welcome the money that has been made available for the crop planting scheme, but I believe that that could have been done in far better ways.

Let us look at social security and the one cheque buy-off by which the Government is sending out $125 to families with one child, or a maximum of $250 to those with up to five children. That is a $317m pay out in one week.

As Senator Schacht and Senator Button told us today, the Government has allocated $454m to rail. It is the light on the hill for rail in Australia. Rail will be standardised completely around Australia. The Government has thrown in $454m. This Government, unfunded, will soon be spending $317m in one cheque. Is that buying a vote, or what is it? What an exercise!

TALK.START.PARA: —If only it would put a light at the end of the tunnel, we would know where we were going.

—That is right. There are a couple of points that I welcome in this package. I welcome the $1m feasibility grant for the steel mill in Western Australia. I believe the Government may have to do a little bit more of that if we want to talk about downstreaming to improve Australia's trading position. That is a good way to go and I certainly welcome that.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the $20m sewerage grant for Western Australia. I do not know how it came about. I think it was by default, actually—but nonetheless it is there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe it is to clean up the mess from WA Inc.
—Yes. They might be able to use that to clean out the whole show.

PARA.TAB: We have talked about tax cuts, but there is nothing in the statement whatsoever when you really go into the figures. I could read the figures out exactly as they compare to the Hewson Fightback package. But it does not come within a bull's roar of the Hewson package. No doubt I will find other opportunities in this Senate to debate this package later on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be ever so brief. I could take some time to explain the intrinsic relationship between the FinancIal Legislation Amendment Bill and what I am about to say. However, it would be quicker for me not to do that and just get on with what I am about to say.

PARA.TAB: I begin back to front by making brief mention of the economic statement delivered by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Let us remember that it is the sixteenth occasion that this man, either as Prime Minister or as Treasurer, has made what he claims to be a profound economic statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many times?
—Sixteen occasions.
—No, there have been nineteen.

—Perhaps there have been three that have passed me, that are forever lost over the horizon. Each of these has been a milestone in progression along the road to a better and greater Australia. We have had them bringing home the bacon. We have had them setting the sails for full steam ahead. We have had all sorts of things. The truth of the matter is that none of them have had a beneficial effect on Australia.

PARA.TAB: This statement, of course, is breathtaking in its audacity. It contains about $18 billion in unfunded commitments. For the last two years this Government has been hammering the Opposition, asking where the money is coming from. We have $18 billion of unfunded commitments. The Government is on a wing and a prayer. It is `Trust me' stuff. What is audacious about it is that if anybody asks to be trusted, it is Mr Keating. This package is no different from all the other packages and all the other promises.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great record of trust.
—A great record of trust!
—Don't prompt him; he is doing all right.

—If you were married to this man, you would have to start to doubt whether he could be trusted. The truth of the matter is that this is a political statement—not an economic document—made for political purposes. It is no different from the political statements that he has made throughout his career. It is no different from the decision that was made in respect of Coronation Hill and his recent reaffirmation of that decision. It was made, originally, to appease the left wing and get the preferences of the green vote.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, to lock in the left wing, prior to getting his numbers, had to make a commitment that he would not reverse that nonsensical, obscene decision. That was a decision made for political purposes. It did not matter how it affected Australia. It does not matter that we are about to have before us resource legislation as a result of companies not trusting this Government. It was a decision made in his best interests, in the same vein as the recent decision to continue with the abolition of the co-payment for Medicare. Mr Keating knows that that is economic lunacy but, because he had locked in some members of the Centre Left faction, he was unable to reverse that decision. That was another political decision that has cost millions and millions of dollars.

This document is not about good government, a better Australia or good economics. It is all about Mr Keating seeking to get elected for another term. The One Nation statement has nothing to do with fundamentally changing the underlying ills of the Australian economy or addressing the fundamental structural defects which impair its capacity to grow. It is simply throwing billions of dollars into structural reform, which will not change work practices, make us any more competitive or change the underlying structural problems of this country.

It is a statement which is simply a knee-jerk reaction to the coalition's Fightback package. As I say, the One Nation document has been prepared for political reasons. It is a document designed exclusively to get the Prime Minister and this Government re-elected. This document was designed on the premise that it had to be starkly different from that which has been offered by the Opposition. It did not matter what it was—`Just make it somehow different'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did Treasury scrutinise him?

—Mr Keating allegedly had had a bad experience with Treasury. He had eight years of disasters, so he thought this time around he would try to do it without Treasury. It is a document designed to bribe the electorate with unfunded tax cuts to be delivered in the far distant future. It is a document designed to pump prime the economy before the next election regardless of what intrinsic growth is already in the economy.

PARA.TAB: It is irrelevant that it might again drive up inflation, interest rates and the exchange rate. It does not matter that essentially it might provide evil for the economy. What is important for this Government is that the economy is given a spurt in growth prior to the next election. As I say, this is a document which does absolutely nothing economically. It simply provides political goals. It is a document which is designed to look different from Fightback!.

Of course, we have the same man who, as Treasurer in the 1980s, did not understand that the structural rigidity of this country is such that any growth past about 2.5 per cent suddenly creates a massive problem with the current account deficit and the foreign debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is about $140 billion, isn't it?

—Yes, and a great deal more under this. We have not set about changing the structural problems and then setting the stage for growth. What we are doing now is making another dash for growth without changing those structural impediments.

PARA.TAB: What I find audacious about Mr Keating, particularly in the last few days, is that he seems to have learnt nothing. There is no remorse or self-examination. There is no change in a man who has given us a million unemployed and under whom 30 per cent of young people are unemployed. He is someone who has delivered half a million children into poverty. He is a man who has presided over a situation under which something like 75,000 children do not have a home or a bed that they can call their own.

TALK.START.PARA: —He gave us the recession, too.

—He gave us the recession which he says we had to have. We did not have to have the recession. The reason we have the recession is because of his incompetence and failures as a Treasurer during the 1980s. There was nothing inevitable about a recession in this country. The One Nation statement will do absolutely nothing to help the poor, the disadvantaged and the disabled. It does nothing about providing tax cuts for those 50 per cent of taxpayers—the four million people—who earn less than $21,000 a year.

PARA.TAB: I said I would speak for but five minutes and I will do so. I hope that we will get another opportunity to debate this package. I have no doubt that, as time proceeds and there is a greater realisation of the comparison between the two documents, this One Nation document will be seen for what it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Having sought the cooperation of Opposition senators to at least curtail their remarks, if not relate them too tightly to the Financial Legislation Amendment Bill, I will not abuse the procedures by now making a very lengthy response to all the points that various people raised. But there will be, I am sure, ample opportunity to debate the various major economic issues that people have raised in speaking to this Bill.

PARA.TAB: I had the opportunity to speak on this matter last week in the Senate, and I do not intend to rehash all of what I said. I need to make some brief comments on some of the matters that were raised, but I certainly do not intend to make a lengthy response. There are some things that need to be emphasised.

We now have the situation in the public policy debate in Australia that the only group opposing the injection of a stimulus by the Government into the economy is the Opposition. Business groups might argue about the size, some advocating more than others, but the Opposition is the only group arguing that there should be no fiscal stimulus.

We had a debate about monetary policy from Senator Short, which sounded very much like the not infrequent expositions in which attempts are made to try to use New Zealand as a role model for the way Australian economic management might go, particularly with regard to the role of the Reserve Bank. I have to say that that is not a role model that anyone else in the Western world would seek to emulate. I am very surprised that the Opposition should seek to do so; the Government certainly does not.

One of the obsessions that occurs in the rhetoric—it must have been based on the Liberal Party secretariat speakers' notes—is the continuing reference to the expenditure being unfunded. A breathless excitement—

TALK.START.PARA: —You say `excitement' and I say `great concern'.
—That means the Budget deficit will go up by a little bit.
—A little bit!
—Yes, that is true; it is a very small amount. There is no argument about the fact—
—Can you remember before the last election how many times you asked us about our package, `Where is the money coming from'?

—There is a very significant reason why the circumstances are substantially different now. I did not want to divert onto that but, if I can do so without using up too much time, I will. Let us not argue about the controversial projections three, four or five years out because everybody makes his best estimates. Unlike those opposite, I think both sides have honestly made their best estimates. History will be the judge of who has got it right and who has got it wrong.

PARA.TAB: Next year the biggest projected deficit—1.9 per cent of GDP—is, by Australian historical standards and by international standards, a small deficit, particularly during a recession. There is nothing extraordinary about that. To consider that this will put an enormous pressure on interest rates implies that there will be so much demand for investment next year that there will be a shortage of supply of money to meet this enormous demand.

In a sense, I wish that were true. But one cannot at the one time say that and say also that we will not achieve the rate of growth we are trying to achieve. If that rate of demand stimulus were to be achieved then, first of all, the deficit would fall enormously because the fiscal situation would change dramatically, the automatic stabilisers would work in reverse to the way they are working at the moment, but it would also mean a great rate of growth in jobs.

There was a lot of talk about the redistributive impacts of the respective statements. I will not take up the time of the Senate talking about that now; that debate will take on new meaning from tomorrow with the tabling of certain documents. That is the time to have that debate. It is quite clear that the Opposition's Fightback package means that most Australian taxpayers will pay a lot more tax than they pay now.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolutely wrong.

—Senator Brownhill should wait until tomorrow; I do not want to have the debate now. Nothing is a greater waste of time than having a debate twice, so I will not do it now; we will do it another time.

PARA.TAB: There was great passion, enthusiasm and concern about the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and what an unpopular person he is. I do not think the excitement on the other side is generated by the Prime Minister's unpopularity; I think it is caused by a great fear about his rising popularity, the very significant fall in Dr Hewson's popularity since the middle of January and the fact that those opposite can see the gap narrowing. For the first time we can start to see the fear in their eyes. Those are matters that we will all have lots of time to talk about.

I want to say something about Senator Macdonald's contribution before I come back to the only question that was raised that relates to the Bill. I will do that as soon as I can. Although Senator Macdonald assured me that what he was saying did relate to the Bill, I do not think it did. Nevertheless, I accept that it was important. I agree with a large part of what he said about the nature of advice given to some of the people who got in trouble with foreign currency borrowings. I do not know so much about their relationship with the banks; that is a fairly esoteric question. His advice to people to be cautious when what looks like some sort of magic potion is presented to them by their financial advisers was sound advice.

Senator Macdonald asked me particularly about the Martin Committee report entitled A Pocket Full of Change—the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. The Government has given a commitment to consider and respond to the recommendations of the Standing Committee. As Senator Macdonald remarked, most of the recommendations are things for the banks to do rather than things for the Government to do. They are recommendations—Senator Macdonald directly referred to many of them—about the way in which the banks should change their practices. Some of them are already doing so. Those responses that refer to the Government are being considered, but I cannot give an announcement about a timetable at this stage. I can indicate, as I have indicated to this chamber in debate before, that I for one will not be supporting proposals that we should be moving in the direction of a royal commission. That is entirely the wrong thing to be doing.

I turn to the point raised first by Senator Kernot. Although I heard a large part of her contribution, I did not pick this point up. The telephone started running hot from people who misunderstood what she said or perhaps she misunderstood the Bill. From what I heard, she asked a fairly straightforward question about which some people got excited because they misunderstood her point. Senator Short, whom I did hear, raised the same question. It is a concern about whether there is something more significant than appears on the surface in the nature of the changes to the approval process for coinage under the Currency Act. At the moment, as people who have been involved with debating the Bill would know, the procedures under the Currency Act 1965 require regulations to issue. These will be changed to ministerial determinations.

There is no substantive change whatsoever to the checks and balances that are available within the system. The key check is here. The key check is that the Senate has the capacity to disallow determinations, particularly under this legislation. It is made explicit at proposed new section 13(6) under clause 4 of the Bill that a determination is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act. There is nothing that the Government can do under the Currency Act as it now stands that it cannot do with the amendments and vice versa. There is nothing the Government can do under the Bill that it does not already have the power to do at the moment. All that has happened is that a procedure by which the decision made by the Treasurer has to be processed via the Executive Council and then back to tabling is removed to simplify the process with no substantive effect on the checks and balances available to the chamber, to the Parliament, or the information available to the people more widely.

Senator Short asked me a specific question about the extent of the savings. I do want to exaggerate that. I expect the administrative savings to be very small. The amount of work involved in this is increasing a bit. I deal with it most times. The number of times that it is happening is increasing as the coinage increases because of the role of the Mint and Gold Corp in producing precious metal coins and those sorts of issues over and above the traditional coin issuing. I think there is a small element of saving. We should make those savings we can, but let us not exaggerate the significance of that. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter which was brought to my attention by a short article headed `Bio-fuels may save EC farmers' which appeared in the Financial Review on 19 February this year. I was attracted to read the article—and I will quote briefly from it—because it raises an issue which has received attention from time to time in this place and in other parliaments throughout Australia, that is, alternative fuels which may be distilled from the surplus crops that our farmers sometimes have. We have heard this matter discussed quite often in this place, particularly by senators from Queensland, and I know that Senator Kernot has often introduced this matter.

PARA.TAB: The plight of our canegrowers results from the low world market price for sugar and the inability of our farmers to seek alternative markets. The solution may in part lie in the fact that we could seek alternative crops to be grown on the same land that canegrowers are committed to, but we also may be able to solve this problem by seeking alternative uses for the sugar cane which is grown there. This has been alluded to in the article in the Financial Review. It suggests that the European Community Commission wants Europeans to start fuelling their cars with corn, rapeseed and sugar beets, all products which, in past years, have been grown to some excess in Europe, producing a surplus for which there has been little use.

The Financial Review article states that the European Community Commission has a plan which represents the EC's latest effort to placate its 10 million farmers. We are told that these 10 million farmers fear their jobs are at risk because of current efforts to reform the world trading system. Here we see an imperative that is brought into this argument which is a unique way of solving things. Rather than build up mountains of excess production, which has been the traditional response of the Europeans; and rather than plough in excess production, which has sometimes been used as a so-called solution in Australia; the use of this bio-mass, this organic produce, to distil and produce ethanol for use as an alternative fuel is being considered.

Of course, the immediate advantage to any country adopting this practice would be to improve its balance of payments if it imports oil at all. In Australia's case, it is immediately apparent that our imports of oil may be reduced considerably by following this sort of example.

I raise this tonight simply to suggest that it is not only the crazies of this world—the Democrats, the canegrowers and other people who support canegrowers in Australia—who are suggesting that this may be a solution. The fact is that the European Community Commission is actively considering this possibility right now. We should make a much more concerted effort to look seriously at this potential solution to the problem we have with disposing of the produce of our farms in an economical and beneficial way. I hope to take other opportunities to introduce ideas from overseas that we should be taking advantage of.

PARA.TAB: (2) Compass Airlines ceased flying operations on 20 December 1991, and the Company's affairs were put in the hands of a provisional liquidator. The Archives Act includes special provisions for the custody of and access to Royal Commission records, including commissions held jointly by the Commonwealth and State and Territory Governments. Standard arrangements relating to the custody of and access to records of joint Royal Commissions have been agreed between the Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory Governments.
The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody made the following recommendations (Recommendation 57) in relation to its records:
That Governments agree that:
a. The records of the Commission be held in archives in the capital city of the state in which the inquiry, which gathered those records, occurred; and

b. A relevant Aboriginal body, for example the Aboriginal Affairs Planning Authority in the case of Western Australia, be given responsibility for determining access (to) the material jointly with the normal authority for determining such matters.

Implementation of this recommendation is still being considered by the Commonwealth Government in consultation with the State and Territory Governments and representatives of Aboriginal people. Once agreement is reached on the implementation of Recommendation 57 consideration can be given to Senator Tambling's request.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia, upon notice on 29 January 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the North Australia Economic Development Strategy currently being undertaken by the Centre for Applied Economic Research and Analysis at James Cook University, Townsville, Queensland:
(1) What funding has been allocated to this study to date.
(2) What future funding and research proposals are anticipated.

(3) Has a copy of the interim report entitled, The Delineation of Northern Australia and Some Features of its Economy, Information Paper No. 1, September 1991, been made available to the department; if so, can a copy be made available to the Senate.
(4) When is it anticipated that further reports will be made available.
(5) Will this consultancy come under the Office of Northern Development when it starts operating from the department on 1 March 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) A total of $155,512 has been appropriated for this study, of which $124,409.60 has been paid to the consultant in progress payments to date.
(2) At this stage, there are no plans for further funding and research proposals of this kind involving consultants.
(3) A copy of Information Paper No. 1 has been received by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, and a copy has been provided to the Parliamentary Library.

(4) Information Paper No. 2, The Mining Industry in North Queensland and Prospects for Development, has been received by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, and a copy has been provided to the Parliamentary Library. The consultant currently intends to prepare a third information paper, which would deal with the economy of the Northern Territory and would be finalised in April 1992. The consultant had originally intended to prepare further information and discussion papers for publication prior to completion of the final report. This approach has now been curtailed to expedite progress on the main elements of the final report, which are anticipated to cover: the economy of northern Australia; prospects, opportunities and constraints relating to its development; and strategies for its economic development. The contract with the consultant requires the final report to be provided by 30 June 1992.
(5) Yes.
